questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, distention, and fever. He reports having bloody diarrhea and has been using mesalamine and prednisone to manage his condition. On physical examination, his abdomen is tender and distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory tests indicate leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Toxic megacolon

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Pneumatosis intestinalis involves the presence of gas cysts in the bowel wall , which is not indicated in this X-ray.
  • • Option A:
  • • Pneumatosis intestinalis
  • • presence of gas cysts
  • • bowel wall
  • • Option B: Perforation peritonitis would show free air under the diaphragm , which is not visible here.
  • • Option B:
  • • Perforation peritonitis
  • • free air under the diaphragm
  • • Option C: Diverticulitis typically presents with localized colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding .
  • • Option C:
  • • Diverticulitis
  • • localized colonic wall thickening
  • • pericolic fat stranding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic radiographic findings of dilated colon segments and clinical symptoms suggest toxic megacolon , especially in a patient with a history of inflammatory bowel disease .
  • ➤ radiographic findings
  • ➤ dilated colon segments
  • ➤ toxic megacolon
  • ➤ inflammatory bowel disease
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-292, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-292, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: Drugs decreasing bone resorption in osteoporosis are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Teriparatide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It works by binding to estrogen receptors in bone.
  • • Option A. Raloxifene:
  • • Option C. Strontium: Strontium ranelate is a medication that was used for osteoporosis. It was believed to have a dual effect, both promoting bone formation and inhibiting bone resorption.
  • • Option C. Strontium:
  • • Option D. Risedronate: Risedronate belongs to a class of drugs known as bisphosphonates. Bisphosphonates are potent inhibitors of bone resorption. They work by inhibiting osteoclast activity, reducing bone turnover, and increasing bone mineral density
  • • Option D. Risedronate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Drug that do not decrease bone resorption in osteoporosis is Teripartide. Teriparatide is a PTH analogue and is given subcutaneously on anterior abdominal wall or anterolateral aspect of thigh.
  • ➤ Drug that do not decrease bone resorption in osteoporosis is Teripartide.
  • ➤ Teriparatide is a PTH analogue and is given subcutaneously on anterior abdominal wall or anterolateral aspect of thigh.

questions.text: What is the appearance of CSF on T1 weight MRI-T2 weighted MRI -FLAIR respectively?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hypointense -Hyperintense-Hypointense

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • MRI sequences are essential tools for distinguishing between different types of tissue based on their appearance under various imaging conditions:
  • • MRI sequences
  • • distinguishing between different types of tissue
  • • T1-weighted images: CSF appears hypointense (dark) compared to the brain parenchyma . White matter appears hyperintense (bright) relative to gray matter. T2-weighted images: CSF appears hyperintense (bright) as it contains a high amount of water . Conversely, white matter appears hypointense compared to gray matter. FLAIR (Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery): CSF signal is suppressed , making it appear hypointense (dark), which helps to detect lesions , such as those caused by demyelination , edema , or infarction , which may appear hyperintense (bright).
  • • T1-weighted images: CSF appears hypointense (dark) compared to the brain parenchyma . White matter appears hyperintense (bright) relative to gray matter.
  • • T1-weighted images:
  • • CSF
  • • hypointense
  • • brain parenchyma
  • • T2-weighted images: CSF appears hyperintense (bright) as it contains a high amount of water . Conversely, white matter appears hypointense compared to gray matter.
  • • T2-weighted images:
  • • CSF
  • • hyperintense
  • • high amount of water
  • • FLAIR (Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery): CSF signal is suppressed , making it appear hypointense (dark), which helps to detect lesions , such as those caused by demyelination , edema , or infarction , which may appear hyperintense (bright).
  • • FLAIR (Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery):
  • • CSF signal
  • • suppressed
  • • hypointense
  • • detect lesions
  • • demyelination
  • • edema
  • • infarction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the signal characteristics of CSF across different MRI sequences is fundamental for interpreting brain images . CSF is typically dark on T1-weighted images , bright on T2-weighted images , and dark again on FLAIR images due to the suppression of the fluid signal to better detect pathology.
  • ➤ signal characteristics of CSF
  • ➤ different MRI sequences
  • ➤ fundamental
  • ➤ brain images
  • ➤ CSF
  • ➤ dark on T1-weighted images
  • ➤ bright
  • ➤ T2-weighted images
  • ➤ MRI SEQUENCES
  • ➤ MRI SEQUENCES

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a smoking history of 36 pack years presents with numbness and weakness of the right hand and arm and tingling in the fingers. There is associated drooping of the right eye with miosis. What is the IOC for the patient?

options.label: B
options.text: USG Doppler of right upper limb

questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms suggest a Pancoast tumor , which is a type of lung cancer located at the apex of the lung . It can cause damage to the brachial plexus and sympathetic chain , leading to the observed neurological and autonomic symptoms . MRI is the investigation of choice because it offers superior soft tissue contrast resolution, allowing for detailed assessment of the tumor's involvement with the brachial plexus , sympathetic chain , and adjacent structures . MRI is more precise than CT in determining the extent of local invasion, which is crucial for planning treatment.
  • • Pancoast tumor
  • • type of lung cancer
  • • apex of the lung
  • • cause damage
  • • brachial plexus
  • • sympathetic chain
  • • neurological and autonomic symptoms
  • • MRI
  • • investigation
  • • choice
  • • superior soft tissue contrast resolution,
  • • tumor's involvement
  • • brachial plexus
  • • sympathetic chain
  • • adjacent structures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient present with symptoms indicative of a Pancoast tumor , such as arm weakness and numbness along with signs of Horner's syndrome , MRI is the preferred imaging modality to assess the extent of local tumor invasion , particularly involving the brachial plexus and sympathetic chain . This information is vital for staging the disease and planning appropriate management.
  • ➤ Pancoast tumor
  • ➤ arm weakness
  • ➤ numbness
  • ➤ signs of Horner's syndrome
  • ➤ MRI
  • ➤ preferred imaging modality
  • ➤ assess the extent of local tumor invasion
  • ➤ brachial plexus
  • ➤ sympathetic chain

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient comes to the OPD with complaints of a swelling on the eyelid. He gives history of a similar complaint multiple times in the past. The ophthalmologist diagnoses it as a case of recurrent chalazion and sends it for histopathological examination. What is the ophthalmologist excluding the probability of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma : This is a type of skin cancer that can occur on the eyelids , often resulting from prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light . While it can present as a lesion on the eyelid, its clinical appearance is usually different from that of a chalazion , typically showing more superficial, scaly, and ulcerative features .
  • • Option A.
  • • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • • type of skin cancer
  • • occur on the eyelids
  • • resulting from prolonged exposure to ultraviolet
  • • light
  • • lesion on the eyelid,
  • • clinical appearance is usually different from that of a chalazion
  • • superficial, scaly, and ulcerative features
  • • Option B . Basal Cell Carcinoma : The most common type of eyelid cancer , basal cell carcinoma often presents as a painless , slowly growing nodule on the eyelid with potential ulceration or a pearly appearance.
  • • Option B
  • • Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • • most common type of eyelid cancer
  • • basal cell carcinoma
  • • presents as a painless
  • • growing nodule on the eyelid
  • • potential ulceration
  • • Option C. Malignant Melanoma : This is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-containing cells known as melanocytes.
  • • Option C.
  • • Malignant Melanoma
  • • type of cancer that develops from the pigment-containing cells
  • • melanocytes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The histopathological examination of a recurrent chalazion is primarily conducted to exclude the possibility of sebaceous cell carcinoma .
  • ➤ histopathological examination of a recurrent chalazion
  • ➤ conducted to exclude the possibility
  • ➤ sebaceous cell carcinoma
  • ➤ Ref : pg 369 – eyelids- 6 th edition – comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: A research team is exploring the metabolic adaptations of cancer cells and how these cells meet their increased energy demands. In most cancer cells, the predominant metabolic pathway for generating the necessary energy is distinct from that of normal, non-cancerous cells. Which metabolic process do cancer cells primarily exploit to derive the energy needed for their rapid growth and proliferation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycolysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Oxidative phosphorylation : While important in many tissues, cancer cells rely less on oxidative phosphorylation compared to normal cells , partially because it is less efficient under hypoxic conditions, which are common in tumors.
  • • Option B. Oxidative phosphorylation
  • • cancer cells
  • • less
  • • oxidative phosphorylation
  • • normal cells
  • • less efficient under hypoxic conditions,
  • • common in tumors.
  • • Option C. TCA cycle in mitochondria : The TCA cycle is used by all cells , but cancer cells often have mitochondrial defects that reduce their reliance on this pathway.
  • • Option C. TCA cycle in mitochondria
  • • TCA cycle
  • • all cells
  • • cancer cells
  • • mitochondrial defects
  • • reduce
  • • reliance
  • • pathway.
  • • Option D. Beta-oxidation : This pathway oxidizes fatty acids to generate acetyl-CoA for energy ; however, cancer cells typically rely on this less than on glycolysis.
  • • Option D. Beta-oxidation
  • • oxidizes fatty acids
  • • acetyl-CoA for energy
  • • cancer cells
  • • rely on
  • • less
  • • glycolysis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cancer cells predominantly use glycolysis for energy production, even in the presence of oxygen, a phenomenon known as the Warburg effect. This metabolic adaptation allows cancer cells to thrive even under hypoxic conditions and contributes to the acidic microenvironment often seen in tumors due to lactate production.
  • ➤ Cancer cells
  • ➤ glycolysis for energy production,
  • ➤ presence of oxygen,
  • ➤ Warburg effect.
  • ➤ adaptation allows cancer cells to thrive
  • ➤ hypoxic conditions
  • ➤ acidic
  • ➤ microenvironment
  • ➤ tumors
  • ➤ lactate production.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e p738.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Harper 30/e p738.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with abdominal pain and a pelvic mass. Histological examination of the ovarian tumor reveals the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Yolk sac tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Dysgerminoma are type of ovarian germ cell tumor , but they are characterized by monotonous sheets of large , undifferentiated cells resembling primordial germ cells .

  • • ovarian germ cell tumor
  • • monotonous sheets of large
  • • undifferentiated cells

  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Teratoma

  • • contain a variety of tissues
  • • epithelium, hair
  • • cartilage
  • • Option D . Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors , and they are characterized by the presence of Call-Exner bodies . These bodies are small, eosinophilic fluid-filled spaces surrounded by granulosa cells.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Granulosa cell tumors
  • • sex cord-stromal tumors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies in an ovarian mass biopsy is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumors , also known as endodermal sinus tumors , and is the most likely diagnosis in a young woman presenting with these histological findings.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male is rushed to the emergency department of a tertiary care hospital in India after being bitten by a snake while working in the fields. He has no significant medical history. On examination, he is anxious, with a bite mark visible on his lower right leg. Within hours, he develops hematuria and laboratory tests indicate a rapid deterioration in renal function. The medical team considers the type of enzyme present in the snake venom that might be responsible for these clinical findings. Which enzyme in snake venom is known to cause hematuria and renal function deterioration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Option A. Phospholipase A1 is not typically associated with the clinical effects described.

It can lead to hematuria and acute kidney injury either by direct renal toxicity or through the effects of hemoglobin and myoglobin breakdown products.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension presents with mild abdominal discomfort and is found to have a pulsatile mass on abdominal examination. His blood pressure is well-controlled on antihypertensive medication. Which of the following is the most common cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atherosclerosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: While syphilis can cause aortic aneurysms , it is less common in contemporary medicine due to the widespread use of antibiotics. Atherosclerosis is a more prevalent and frequent cause.

  • • aortic aneurysms
  • • less common
  • • antibiotics.

  • • atherosclerosis
  • • Traumatic aneurysms
  • • severe injuries or accidents
  • • Option D: Congenital factors can contribute to the development of aortic aneurysms , but they are less common compared to acquired conditions . Atherosclerosis is still a more prevalent cause in the adult population.
  • • Option D:
  • • Congenital factors
  • • aortic aneurysms
  • • less
  • • acquired conditions
  • • Atherosclerosis
  • • more prevalent
  • • adult population.
  • • Educational objective:

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with jaundice and anemia. His blood smear shows spherical red blood cells, and laboratory tests reveal an increase in mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.  Hereditary spherocytosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • Option B. Megaloblastic anemia: It can be associated with vitamin B12 or folate deficiency and ha s macrocytosis . This condition is associated with a normal or decreased MCHC.
  • • Option B. Megaloblastic anemia:
  • • vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
  • • s macrocytosis
  • • normal or decreased MCHC.
  • • Option C. Anemia of chronic disease: The anomie is often normocytic and normochromic , with a normal MCH
  • • Option C. Anemia of chronic disease:
  • • normocytic and normochromic
  • • normal MCH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hereditary spherocytosis often presents with an elevated MCHC due to the spherical shape of red blood cells , which concentrates the haemoglobin content

questions.text: An elderly patient dies due to a cancer and his cells in the cancer affected area were examined. Ultra structurally, the most prominent features found are the loss of mitochondrial cristae and ruptured outer mitochondrial membrane. Which of the following best can be the pattern of cell death here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ferroptosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Necrosis is a form of cell death characterized by uncontrolled cell lysis , often resulting in inflammation.
  • • Option A. Necrosis
  • • cell death
  • • uncontrolled cell lysis
  • • inflammation.
  • • Option B. Necroptosis is a type of programmed necrosis that is dependent on receptor-interacting protein kinases and often associated with inflammation.
  • • Option B. Necroptosis
  • • programmed necrosis
  • • receptor-interacting protein kinases
  • • Option D. Pyroptosis is an inflammatory form of programmed cell death associated with the activation of caspase-1 and often seen in immune cells.
  • • Option D. Pyroptosis
  • • inflammatory form of programmed cell death
  • • activation of caspase-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ferroptosis is a regulated cell death pathway marked by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation , resulting in distinctive ultrastructural changes such as loss of mitochondrial cristae and rupture of the outer mitochondrial membrane , commonly associated with cancer, neurodegeneration, and stroke .
  • ➤ Ferroptosis
  • ➤ regulated cell death pathway marked by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation
  • ➤ loss of mitochondrial cristae and rupture of the outer mitochondrial membrane
  • ➤ cancer, neurodegeneration, and stroke

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought to the OPD with a history of drooping upper left eyelid since birth. What is the surgical procedure performed to correct ptosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Frontalis sling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Fasanella-Servat : This procedure is typically used for mild ptosis with good levator function . It involves resection of a small amount of the tarsal plate and Müller’s muscle but is not commonly used for congenital ptosis.
  • • Option B
  • • Fasanella-Servat
  • • used for mild ptosis with good levator function
  • • resection of a small amount of the tarsal plate and Müller’s muscle
  • • Option C . Levator Resection : Levator resection is preferred in cases of congenital ptosis with moderate levator function . The levator muscle is shortened, which helps to elevate the eyelid.
  • • Option C
  • • Levator Resection
  • • preferred in cases of congenital ptosis with moderate levator function
  • • Option D. Levator Advancement : Levator advancement is similar to levator resection and may be used for ptosis with good levator function . This procedure involves advancing the levator aponeurosis to effectively shorten and strengthen the muscle, helping to lift the eyelid.
  • • Option D.
  • • Levator Advancement
  • • levator resection and may be used for ptosis with good levator function

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For congenital ptosis , especially with poor levator function , the Frontalis Sling operation is often the surgery of choice.
  • ➤ congenital ptosis

questions.text: The X Ray of the skull as shown in the image given below is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hyperparathyroidism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a hematological condition where malignant plasma cells proliferate in the bone marrow . It can lead to "punched out" lytic bone lesions on X-rays due to localized areas of bone resorption , but these tend to be larger than those seen in hyperparathyroidism and are often associated with other systemic symptoms.
  • • Option B. Multiple Myeloma:
  • • hematological condition
  • • malignant plasma cells proliferate
  • • bone marrow
  • • "punched out" lytic bone lesions
  • • X-rays
  • • localized areas of bone resorption
  • • Option C. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism can lead to osteoporosis , it is not typically characterized by the "salt and pepper" appearance seen in hyperparathyroidism. The bone changes in hyperthyroidism are more diffuse and less likely to present as discrete lytic lesions on the skull X-ray.
  • • Option C. Hyperthyroidism:
  • • lead to osteoporosis
  • • not
  • • by the "salt and pepper" appearance
  • • Option D. Paget's Disease: Paget's disease of bone involves abnormal bone remodeling , leading to enlarged and deformed bones . Radiographically, it can present with thickened cortical bone and areas of osteolysis, but the appearance is generally more disorganized and expansive than the discrete lytic lesions seen in hyperparathyroidism.
  • • Option D. Paget's Disease:
  • • abnormal bone remodeling
  • • leading to enlarged
  • • deformed bones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "salt and pepper" appearance on skull X-ray , characterized by multiple tiny radiolucent lytic lesions due to bone resorption by PTH , is indicative of hyperparathyroidism.

  • ➤ skull X-ray

  • ➤ bone resorption by PTH
  • ➤ hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Needle-shaped crystals negatively birefringent on polarized microscopy is characteristic of which crystal-associated arthropathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gout

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. CPPD: CPPD, or pseudogout, is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints. These crystals are rhomboid-shaped and are positively birefringent under polarized light.
  • • Option B. CPPD:
  • • Option C. Neuropathic arthropathy: Neuropathic arthropathy is associated with nerve damage, often seen in conditions such as diabetes. It is characterized by joint damage and deformities due to the loss of sensation and proprioception. Crystal deposition is not a typical feature of neuropathic arthropathy.
  • • Option C. Neuropathic arthropathy:
  • • Option D. Hemophilic arthropathy: Hemophilic arthropathy is a condition that affects joints in individuals with hemophilia. It is characterized by recurrent bleeding into the joints, leading to chronic inflammation, synovial hypertrophy, and joint damage. Crystals are not typically associated with hemophilic arthropathy.
  • • Option D. Hemophilic arthropathy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. These crystals appear as needle-shaped and are negatively birefringent when viewed under polarized light.
  • ➤ Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints.
  • ➤ These crystals appear as needle-shaped and are negatively birefringent when viewed under polarized light.

questions.text: Tuberculosis in bone is due to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Paucibacillary and hematogenous

  • • Option D. Multibacillary and lymphatic
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Tuberculosis of bone occurs due to spread from the hematogenous route from a primary site, usually lungs. The lesions in bone TB are paucibacillary i.e., the skin smear appears to be negative and there is no advancement evident on biopsy.
  • • Tuberculosis of bone occurs due to spread from the hematogenous route from a primary site, usually lungs.
  • • Tuberculosis of bone occurs due to spread from the hematogenous route from a primary site, usually lungs.
  • • The lesions in bone TB are paucibacillary i.e., the skin smear appears to be negative and there is no advancement evident on biopsy.

questions.text: Assertion (A ): Proton beam therapy is used for chordoma Reason (R): Chordoma arises from notochordal remnants

options.label: A
options.text: If both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: If both A and R are correct, and R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: If A is correct, but R is wrong

options.label: D
options.text: If A is wrong, but R is correct

questions.correct_answer: B. If both A and R are correct, and R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. If both A and R are correct, and R is not the correct explanation of A

Explanation:

  • • Explanations
  • • :
  • • Proton beam therapy is an effective treatment option for chordoma , which is a rare and slow-growing tumor that often occurs in the skull base and spine . Chordomas are often difficult to treat due to their location and tendency to recur , and traditional radiation therapy can cause significant damage to surrounding healthy tissues.
  • • Proton beam therapy
  • • effective treatment option for chordoma
  • • rare
  • • slow-growing tumor
  • • skull base and spine
  • • Chordomas
  • • difficult to treat
  • • location and tendency to recur
  • • Proton therapy offers a more precise form of radiation that delivers a higher dose to the tumor while minimizing exposure to nearby organs and tissues called as Bragg’s peak .
  • • Proton therapy
  • • precise form of radiation
  • • higher dose
  • • tumor
  • • minimizing exposure to nearby organs
  • • Bragg’s peak

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Proton beam therapy is utilized for the treatment of chordoma because of its precision in delivering high radiation doses to the tumor , with minimal exposure to surrounding healthy tissues . This advanced treatment approach is beneficial due to the complex location of chordomas , which originate from notochordal remnants . While the origin of chordoma provides context for its occurrence, it does not explain the specific use of proton beam therapy over other treatment modalities.
  • ➤ Proton beam therapy
  • ➤ treatment of chordoma
  • ➤ precision
  • ➤ delivering high radiation doses
  • ➤ tumor
  • ➤ minimal exposure
  • ➤ surrounding healthy tissues
  • ➤ complex location of chordomas
  • ➤ notochordal remnants

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl with a history of recurrent pulmonary infections is found to have a congenital deficiency of adenosine deaminase, which is associated with a virtual absence of lymphocytes in her peripheral lymphoid organs. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Severe combined immunodeficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia: This is a disorder characterized by the absence of B cells and low levels of all immunoglobulins, but it does not typically involve T cells or adenosine deaminase deficiency.
  • • Option A: Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia:
  • • B cells and low levels of all immunoglobulins,
  • • Option B: DiGeorge syndrome: This condition is due to thymic hypoplasia or aplasia, leading to T cell deficiency . While it may present with recurrent infections , it is not associated with adenosine deaminase deficiency.
  • • Option B: DiGeorge syndrome:
  • • thymic hypoplasia or aplasia,
  • • T cell deficiency
  • • recurrent infections
  • • Option C: Isolated IgA deficiency: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency and usually presents with recurrent mucosal infections . It is characterized by low or absent IgA levels but does not involve a global lack of lymphocytes or adenosine deaminase deficiency .
  • • Option C: Isolated IgA deficiency:
  • • primary immunodeficiency
  • • recurrent mucosal infections
  • • low or absent IgA
  • • global lack of lymphocytes or adenosine deaminase deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SCID is a group of disorders involving both B and T cell deficiencies . Adenosine deaminase deficiency is a specific form of SCID that leads to the accumulation of metabolites toxic to lymphocytes, resulting in their absence.
  • ➤ SCID
  • ➤ B and T cell deficiencies
  • ➤ Adenosine deaminase deficiency
  • ➤ SCID
  • ➤ metabolites toxic to lymphocytes, resulting in their absence.

questions.text: A patient with swelling foot, pus discharge, multiple sinuses. KOH smear shows filamentous structures. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Madura mycosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteomyelitis. Presenting complaints are Fever (>38.3˚C), swelling of the limb, pain, systemic symptoms and increased levels of total leucocyte counts, ESR and CRP. Blood Culture is positive for staphylococcus aureus in 60% cases.
  • • Option A. Osteomyelitis.
  • • Option C. Anthrax. This commonly presents with non-specific prodromal symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and sweats which progress to dyspnea and ultimately, respiratory failure and hemodynamic collapse. In cutaneous anthrax, the diagnosis is mostly clinical. However, confirmation can be established by the culture of the lesion, serologic testing, or punch biopsy. In inhalation anthrax, CT scanning of the chest is more sensitive. Sputum culture, gram stain, and blood cultures are not helpful in the acute phase.
  • • Option C. Anthrax.
  • • Option D. Actinomycosis. It frequently occurs at an oral, cervical or facial site, usually as a soft tissue swelling, abscess or mass that is often mistaken for neoplasm. Angle of jaw is most commonly involved. Involvement of bone is usually due to adjacent soft tissues. Mandible is most commonly involved. Vertebrae (spreading from lung or gut) or pelvis (spreading from cecum or colon) may also be involved. Infection of an extremity is uncommon. X-ray show cystic areas of bone destruction with concomitant bone formation and bone destruction.
  • • Option D. Actinomycosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given symptoms and the smear result is suggestive of Madura mycosis. The filamentous structures observed on a KOH smear in Madura mycosis are hyphae which are the thread-like structures that make up the body of a fungus. In Madura mycosis, the hyphae are typically thick-walled and septate (divided into compartments). This presents as swelling of the extremity, pus discharge, and multiple sinuses.
  • ➤ The given symptoms and the smear result is suggestive of Madura mycosis.
  • ➤ The given symptoms and the smear result is suggestive of Madura mycosis.
  • ➤ The filamentous structures observed on a KOH smear in Madura mycosis are hyphae which are the thread-like structures that make up the body of a fungus.
  • ➤ The filamentous structures observed on a KOH smear in Madura mycosis are hyphae which are the thread-like structures that make up the body of a fungus.
  • ➤ In Madura mycosis, the hyphae are typically thick-walled and septate (divided into compartments).
  • ➤ In Madura mycosis, the hyphae are typically thick-walled and septate (divided into compartments).
  • ➤ This presents as swelling of the extremity, pus discharge, and multiple sinuses.
  • ➤ This presents as swelling of the extremity, pus discharge, and multiple sinuses.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female with no previous medical history, was brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. During evaluation, hyphema in the left eye was detected. Which of the following conditions does not require surgical intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Total hyphema within 1 hour

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for > 5 Days : Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) is a significant concern in hyphema . Persistent elevation (IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for more than 5 days) despite medical therapy (like topical beta-blockers, alpha agonists, and systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors) may indicate the need for surgical intervention . This is to prevent optic nerve damage and other complications associated with prolonged elevated IOP.
  • • Option A.
  • • IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for > 5 Days
  • • Elevated intraocular pressure
  • • hyphema
  • • Persistent elevation
  • • despite medical therapy
  • • indicate the need for surgical intervention
  • • Option B. Corneal Blood Staining : This occurs when red blood cells and hemoglobin infiltrate the corneal stroma . It is a severe complication of hyphema, especially in the setting of high IOP . Corneal blood staining is more likely when there is total hyphema or repeated bleeding. Surgical intervention is often recommended to prevent permanent visual impairment due to corneal opacity.
  • • Option B.
  • • Corneal Blood Staining
  • • occurs when red blood cells
  • • hemoglobin infiltrate the corneal stroma
  • • severe complication of hyphema, especially in the setting of high IOP
  • • Option C. IOP > 50 mmHg for >24 Hours : This is a critical condition. An IOP greater than 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours is a medical emergency due to the risk of optic nerve damage and other complications, such as corneal blood staining. Immediate surgical intervention is typically required to reduce the pressure and prevent irreversible damage.
  • • Option C.
  • • IOP > 50 mmHg for >24 Hours
  • • IOP greater than 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours is a medical emergency due to the risk of optic nerve damage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of hyphema following trauma , surgical intervention is typically indicated for IOP ≥ 25 mmHg lasting more than 5 days , corneal blood staining, and IOP > 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours . However, total hyphema within 1 hour of injury usually does not require immediate surgical intervention unless complications develop.
  • ➤ management of hyphema following trauma
  • ➤ surgical intervention
  • ➤ IOP ≥ 25 mmHg lasting more than 5 days
  • ➤ IOP > 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours
  • ➤ Ref : American association of ophthalmology. Https://eyewiki.aao.org/hyphema
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : American association of ophthalmology. Https://eyewiki.aao.org/hyphema
  • ➤ 2. https://www.aao.org/education/bcscsnippetdetail.aspx?id=31b9e6a0-5abe-4f7c-b457-ceafadddab3d

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to the OPD with symptoms of weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty speaking, hypertension, confusion, and significant weight loss exceeding 7 kgs. He has a history of osteoarthritis and reports consuming 100,000 units of Vitamin D daily for the past 3 months. His laboratory results show a plasma calcium level of 15.5 mg/dL. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Hypercalcemia: Here the blood calcium level is >> 11 mg/dL and there is osteoporosis with X-ray pictures of punched out areas of bone resorption . High calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels and low phosphate levels in blood.

  • • blood calcium level is >> 11 mg/dL
  • • osteoporosis
  • • X-ray pictures of punched out
  • • bone resorption
  • • High calcium
  • • alkaline phosphatase levels
  • • low phosphate levels
  • • Option C: Paget’s disease: It is characterized by osteoclastic bone resorption and disordered replacement of bone , common above 40 years which might affect one or several bones .
  • • Option C: Paget’s disease:
  • • osteoclastic bone resorption
  • • disordered replacement
  • • bone
  • • above 40 years
  • • one or several bones
  • • Option D: Metastatic carcinoma of bone: Drastically high levels of ALP is seen with bone resorption and hypercalcemia.
  • • Option D: Metastatic carcinoma of bone:
  • • high levels of ALP
  • • bone resorption and hypercalcemia.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Vitamin D toxicity leads to hypercalcemia , which can manifest as weakness, polyuria, thirst, confusion, and hypertension due to the increased absorption of calcium from the gut.
  • • Vitamin D toxicity
  • • hypercalcemia
  • • weakness, polyuria, thirst, confusion, and hypertension
  • • increased absorption of calcium

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing a segment of double-stranded DNA as part of an experiment to understand gene expression in a particular type of cancer. The researcher finds that in this DNA segment, thymine makes up 28% of the nucleotides. Based on this information, what is the percentage of guanine in this DNA segment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 22%

Explanation:

  • • Explanations:
  • • Option A . 26%: False
  • • Option A
  • • Option B . 44%: Guanine + Cytosine = 44% (Guanine alone =22%)
  • • Option B
  • • Option C. 56%: Adenine + Thymine = 28 + 28 = 56%
  • • Option C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chargaff's rules emphasize the importance of recognizing that in double-stranded DNA , the percentages of adenine and thymine are equal , as are the percentages of cytosine and guanine .
  • ➤ Chargaff's rules
  • ➤ importance of recognizing
  • ➤ double-stranded DNA
  • ➤ percentages of adenine
  • ➤ thymine are equal
  • ➤ percentages of cytosine

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the glycolytic pathway and is attempting to identify the points of regulation within the process. She notes that certain steps are irreversible and thus play a key role in the regulation of glycolysis. Which of the following enzymes catalyzes a reaction in glycolysis that is not considered irreversible and therefore not a major regulatory point?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enolase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Phosphofructokinase : Catalyzes an irreversible step by converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate and is a major regulatory point of glycolysis.
  • • Option B. Phosphofructokinase
  • • Option C. Pyruvate Kinase : Irreversibly Catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, another regulatory step in glycolysis.
  • • Option C. Pyruvate Kinase
  • • Option D. Hexokinase : Irreversibly phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate at the start of the glycolytic pathway and is allosterically inhibited by its product, making it a key regulatory enzyme.
  • • Option D. Hexokinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Irreversible Steps of Glycolysis:
  • ➤ Hexokinase Phosphofructokinase Pyruvate Kinase

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fatigue and a persistent pallor despite adequate nutrition. The parents report a family history of anemia. A skull X-ray is performed as part of the evaluation. Based on the skull X-ray appearance shown in the image, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Thalassemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Raised ICP: Increased intracranial pressure can lead to several changes in the skull X-ray , such as a separation of sutures in children , erosion of the sella turcica , and sometimes, demineralization of the skull. However, it does not cause the "hair on end" appearance shown in the image.
  • • Option A. Raised ICP:
  • • several changes in the skull X-ray
  • • separation of sutures in children
  • • erosion of the sella turcica
  • • Option B. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is characterized by lytic lesions often referred to as "punched-out" lesions on X-ray . The classic "raindrop" skull appearance can be seen, but it does not present with the vertical striations characteristic of the "hair on end" appearance.
  • • Option B. Multiple Myeloma:
  • • lytic lesions
  • • "punched-out" lesions
  • • X-ray
  • • "raindrop" skull appearance
  • • Option C. Megaloblastic Anemia: Megaloblastic anemia, caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 or folic acid , can also lead to changes in the bone marrow and subsequent skull changes . However, the "hair on end" appearance is not typically seen with megaloblastic anemia.
  • • Option C. Megaloblastic Anemia:
  • • deficiency of vitamin B12 or folic acid
  • • changes in the bone marrow
  • • subsequent skull changes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "hair on end" appearance on skull X-ray is characteristic of hemolytic anemias like thalassemia due to the expansion of diploic space and thickening of trabeculae , indicating the need for effective erythropoiesis.
  • ➤ "hair on end" appearance
  • ➤ skull X-ray
  • ➤ hemolytic anemias
  • ➤ thalassemia
  • ➤ expansion of diploic space
  • ➤ thickening of trabeculae

questions.text: A patient is suffering from carcinoma endometrium and is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation to the whole pelvis. Which of the following organs is most radiosensitive in the pelvic regions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ovary

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Vagina: While the vagina is part of the pelvic radiation field , it is less sensitive to radiation compared to the ovaries. Radiation-induced vaginal changes can include atrophy, stenosis, and dryness, but these are often late effects and less severe than ovarian damage.
  • • Option B. Vagina:
  • • vagina
  • • part of the pelvic radiation field
  • • less sensitive
  • • radiation
  • • Option C. Bladder: The bladder has a moderate level of radiosensitivity . Acute effects of radiation to the bladder can include cystitis , characterized by urgency , frequency , and dysuria . Chronic effects can lead to fibrosis and reduced bladder capacity, but these are generally less frequent than ovarian damage.
  • • Option C. Bladder:
  • • moderate level of radiosensitivity
  • • Acute effects
  • • radiation
  • • bladder
  • • cystitis
  • • urgency
  • • frequency
  • • dysuria
  • • Option D. Rectum: Similar to the bladder, the rectum has a moderate level of radiosensitivity . Acute radiation effects can cause proctitis with symptoms like rectal bleeding, diarrhea, and discomfort. Chronic effects may include fibrosis and strictures, but the ovaries remain the most sensitive due to the presence of rapidly dividing cells.
  • • Option D. Rectum:
  • • rectum
  • • moderate level of radiosensitivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the setting of pelvic irradiation for carcinoma of the endometrium , the ovaries are the most radiosensitive organ due to their high proliferation rate of germ cells , making them susceptible to radiation-induced damage . This can have significant implications for fertility and hormonal function in premenopausal women.
  • ➤ pelvic irradiation for carcinoma
  • ➤ endometrium
  • ➤ ovaries
  • ➤ radiosensitive organ
  • ➤ high proliferation rate of germ cells
  • ➤ susceptible to radiation-induced damage
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 698
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 698

questions.text: A 67-year-old man on biochemical analysis found to have three-fold rise of level of serum alkaline phosphatase to that of upper limit of normal value during a routine checkup but serum calcium and phosphorous concentration and liver function test results are normal. He is asymptomatic. The probable cause is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Paget's disease of bone

Explanation:

  • • Explanations:
  • • Option A. Multiple Myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a malignancy involving plasma cells. Multiple myeloma will have normal ALP.
  • • Option A. Multiple Myeloma.
  • • Option C. Primary hyperthyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by an overactive parathyroid gland, leading to increased levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and subsequent hypercalcemia. In this case, serum calcium levels are reported as normal, making primary hyperparathyroidism less likely.
  • • Option C. Primary hyperthyroidism.
  • • Option D. Osteomalacia. Osteomalacia is a condition of softening of the bones due to a deficiency of vitamin D or problems with its metabolism. It can lead to an increase in alkaline phosphatase. However, serum calcium and phosphorous concentration in osteomalacia would typically be abnormal, with decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate.
  • • Option D. Osteomalacia.

  • ➤ Paget's disease can have high ALP levels, and normal calcium and phosphate.

questions.text: Seema is a 32-year-old office worker who spends most of her day sitting at her desk typing on her computer. Over the past few weeks, she has been experiencing pain and numbness in her right arm, particularly in her hand and fingers. She has also noticed a weakening grip and occasional tingling sensation in her right arm. Her X-ray neck was performed which is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. Cervical Rib

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Costochondritis : This is inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the sternum , which can cause chest pain . The pain from costochondritis may be mistaken for a heart attack or other heart conditions, but it doesn't usually cause numbness in the arm or hands.
  • • Option A. Costochondritis
  • • inflammation of the cartilage
  • • connects a rib to the sternum
  • • cause chest pain
  • • Option C. Rib Fracture 2nd / 3 rd : A fracture in one of the first three ribs can be serious due to the protection they provide to vital chest organs . However, fractures typically present with localized pain and difficulty breathing rather than the arm and hand symptoms described by the patient.
  • • Option C. Rib Fracture 2nd / 3 rd
  • • first three ribs
  • • serious due to the protection
  • • vital chest organs
  • • Option D. C5/C6 Spondylolisthesis : This is a condition where one of the vertebrae in the spine slips out of place onto the vertebra below it , which could be due to a defect or fracture . It can cause localized neck pain and potentially radicular symptoms, but not typically the hand and arm symptoms noted by the patient unless associated with significant nerve root compression.
  • • Option D. C5/C6 Spondylolisthesis
  • • vertebrae in the spine slips out
  • • place onto the vertebra below it
  • • defect or fracture

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a notably protruding abdomen, an umbilical hernia, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, intellectual disability, and short stature, as depicted in the provided picture. Based on these clinical features, what is the most likely diagnosis?

This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, which results in the observed clinical features such as organomegaly (leading to a protuberant abdomen), umbilical hernia , coarse facies, corneal clouding , intellectual disability , and growth retardation.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents, who report that he has been having episodes of cyanosis, especially during feeding and crying. The baby was born at full term without any complications during the pregnancy or delivery. On physical examination, the pediatrician notices that the infant has clubbing of his fingers and toes and a harsh systolic murmur heard best at the upper left sternal border. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Ebstein's Anomaly: Ebstein's anomaly is associated with tricuspid regurgitation and right heart enlargement but does not typically present with a boot-shaped heart on a chest radiograph.

  • • tricuspid regurgitation
  • • right heart enlargement
  • • Option B. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): TGA is a condition where the main arteries (pulmonary artery and aorta) are switched in position (transposed). This leads to cyanosis and heart failure in newborns but does not cause a boot-shaped heart on chest radiograph. It's often diagnosed shortly after birth due to severe cyanosis.
  • • Option B. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA):
  • • main arteries
  • • switched in position
  • • leads to cyanosis
  • • heart failure
  • • newborns
  • • Option D. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (TAPVC): TAPVC is a condition where all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium but instead connect to a systemic vein or the right atrium . It typically presents with cyanosis and signs of heart failure in infancy but not with a boot-shaped heart on radiography.
  • • Option D. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (TAPVC):
  • • all four pulmonary veins
  • • not connect normally to the left atrium
  • • connect to a systemic vein
  • • right atrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) the clinical features of cyanotic episodes , clubbing , and systolic murmur along with the chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Perthes disease?

  • • Option C. It is caused by interruption in the blood supply of the capital femoral epiphyses : This is also true. Perthes disease involves osteonecrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis due to ischemia of the femoral head. Between 4-8 years of age, femoral head depends on the lateral epiphyseal vessels for its blood supply and venous drainage whose situation in retinacula makes them susceptible to stretching and to pressure from an effusion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and distension. She reports that she has been experiencing these symptoms for the past few months, but they have recently become more severe. On examination, her abdomen is distended, and a palpable mass is felt in the right upper quadrant. Her laboratory investigations show an elevated eosinophil count. USG is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pyogenic abscess: Usually presents as an irregular, poorly-defined hypoechoic or anechoic area on ultrasound , often with debris . It may also demonstrate posterior acoustic enhancement due to the liquefactive nature of the abscess . However, the presence of elevated eosinophils is less common in bacterial infections and more characteristic of parasitic infestations.
  • • Option A. Pyogenic abscess:
  • • irregular, poorly-defined hypoechoic
  • • anechoic area
  • • ultrasound
  • • debris
  • • posterior acoustic enhancement
  • • liquefactive nature of the abscess
  • • Option B. Hemangioma: Typically appears on ultrasound as a well-circumscribed, hyperechoic (bright) lesion due to its vascular nature . It does not typically present with elevated eosinophils or cause significant symptoms unless complicated.
  • • Option B. Hemangioma:
  • • well-circumscribed, hyperechoic
  • • vascular nature
  • • Option C. Amoebic abscess : Can present with symptoms similar to those described for the patient, and may show an elevated white blood cell count , often without a significant eosinophilia . On imaging, an amoebic abscess usually appears as a round or oval, hypoechoic lesion without internal structures.
  • • Option C. Amoebic abscess
  • • elevated white blood cell count
  • • without
  • • eosinophilia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient present with chronic abdominal pain , a palpable mass with elevated eosinophils , and ultrasound shows a multiloculated cystic structure , hydatid disease should be considered, particularly in areas where Echinococcus is endemic .
  • ➤ chronic abdominal pain
  • ➤ palpable mass
  • ➤ elevated eosinophils
  • ➤ ultrasound
  • ➤ multiloculated cystic structure
  • ➤ hydatid disease
  • ➤ Echinococcus is endemic

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the pediatric outpatient department with a week-long fever but otherwise normal physical examination findings. To rule out an inborn error of metabolism, a urine screening test is performed, yielding the following results: Benedict’s test - positive Blood Glucose - 110 mg % Bial’s test - positive Urine glucose, fructose and galactose - Negative. What is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Essential pentosuria is a benign, inherited condition caused by a deficiency of L-xylulose reductase , an enzyme of the glucuronic acid pathway . The defect leads to the accumulation and urinary excretion of L-xylulose , a pentose sugar.
  • • benign, inherited condition
  • • L-xylulose reductase
  • • glucuronic acid pathway
  • • L-xylulose
  • • Because L-xylulose is a reducing sugar , it reacts positively with Benedict’s test , even when blood glucose is normal — which is exactly what the lab findings here show.
  • • L-xylulose is a reducing sugar
  • • Benedict’s test
  • • blood glucose is normal
  • • Bial’s test specifically detects pentoses and produces a characteristic blue-green color , confirming the presence of a pentose rather than a hexose (like glucose, fructose, or galactose).
  • • Bial’s test
  • • pentoses
  • • blue-green color
  • • In this case:
  • • Benedict’s test: Positive → Reducing sugar is present. Blood glucose: Normal (110 mg/dL) → rules out diabetes. Urine glucose, fructose, galactose: Negative → excludes common hexose sugars. Bial’s test: Positive → confirms the sugar is a pentose.
  • • Benedict’s test: Positive → Reducing sugar is present.
  • • Benedict’s test: Positive
  • • Blood glucose: Normal (110 mg/dL) → rules out diabetes.
  • • Blood glucose: Normal (110 mg/dL)
  • • Urine glucose, fructose, galactose: Negative → excludes common hexose sugars.
  • • Urine glucose, fructose, galactose: Negative
  • • Bial’s test: Positive → confirms the sugar is a pentose.
  • • Bial’s test: Positive
  • • All this points clearly to essential pentosuria .
  • • essential pentosuria
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B — Essential Fructosuria: Fructose would be detected in urine (fructosuria), confirmed by a positive Seliwanoff’s test (specific for ketohexoses like fructose). Here, fructose is absent, ruling this out. Option C — Hereditary Fructose Intolerance: This condition involves aldolase B deficiency , leading to trapped fructose-1-phosphate . Symptoms include hypoglycemia, vomiting, liver damage when fructose is ingested, and fructose would be present in urine, but here it's negative . Option D — Galactosemia: Characterized by defective metabolism of galactose, usually due to galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency . Galactose would be detectable in urine (but here, it’s negative) and typically presents with cataracts, hepatomegaly.
  • • Option B — Essential Fructosuria: Fructose would be detected in urine (fructosuria), confirmed by a positive Seliwanoff’s test (specific for ketohexoses like fructose). Here, fructose is absent, ruling this out.
  • • Option B — Essential Fructosuria:
  • • positive Seliwanoff’s test
  • • Option C — Hereditary Fructose Intolerance: This condition involves aldolase B deficiency , leading to trapped fructose-1-phosphate . Symptoms include hypoglycemia, vomiting, liver damage when fructose is ingested, and fructose would be present in urine, but here it's negative .
  • • Option C — Hereditary Fructose Intolerance:
  • • aldolase B deficiency
  • • fructose-1-phosphate
  • • negative
  • • Option D — Galactosemia: Characterized by defective metabolism of galactose, usually due to galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency . Galactose would be detectable in urine (but here, it’s negative) and typically presents with cataracts, hepatomegaly.
  • • Option D — Galactosemia:
  • • galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Essential Pentosuria is a harmless, inherited metabolic condition characterized by the excretion of the pentose sugar L-xylulose in urine. This can lead to false-positive results on tests for reducing sugars (Benedict’s) despite normal blood glucose levels. Bial’s test further confirms the presence of pentoses, distinguishing it from hexoses like glucose, fructose, or galactose.
  • ➤ Essential Pentosuria
  • ➤ L-xylulose
  • ➤ Bial’s test
  • ➤ Ref: Harper 30/e: p196, 205.

questions.text: The Following X-ray appearance is suggestive of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Chronic pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute pancreatitis: Typically presents on imaging with pancreatic edema and inflammation but without the calcifications seen in chronic pancreatitis. It can show less specific findings such as enlargement of the pancreas or peripancreatic fluid.
  • • Option A. Acute pancreatitis:
  • • imaging
  • • pancreatic edema
  • • inflammation
  • • without the calcifications
  • • Option C. Carcinoma pancreas: Often presents with a mass lesion , possible dilatation of the pancreatic duct due to obstruction , and at times, a double duct signs on ERCP, which is not evident in the image provided.
  • • Option C. Carcinoma pancreas:
  • • mass lesion
  • • dilatation of the pancreatic duct
  • • obstruction
  • • Option D. Ductal adenoma: Is a rare benign tumor and would not typically present with the diffuse calcifications associated with chronic pancreatitis. It might present as an incidental finding or with non-specific ductal changes on imaging.
  • • Option D. Ductal adenoma:
  • • rare benign tumor
  • • not typically present with the diffuse calcifications

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When an imaging study reveals calcifications along the pancreatic duct and parenchyma , chronic pancreatitis should be considered, especially in the context of a history of alcohol abuse or repeated bouts of acute pancreatitis.
  • ➤ imaging study reveals calcifications
  • ➤ pancreatic duct
  • ➤ parenchyma
  • ➤ chronic pancreatitis
  • ➤ alcohol abuse
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 370
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 370

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient, previously treated for pulmonary tuberculosis, presents with cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. He has been diagnosed with reactivation of tuberculosis. This lesion is most likely to be located near:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Apex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Near bronchus: TB can occur near bronchi, but reactivation often happens in areas with higher oxygen tension.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Near bronchus:
  • • TB
  • • near bronchi,
  • • higher oxygen tension.
  • • Option C. Subpleurally: TB can occur subpleurally, but reactivation is more common in areas with higher oxygen tension.
  • • Option C.
  • • Subpleurally: TB can
  • • subpleurally,
  • • Option D. Base: The base of the lung has lower oxygen perfusion ratio , making it less favorable for reactivated TB.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Base:
  • • lung has lower oxygen perfusion ratio
  • • less favorable
  • • reactivated TB.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reactivated tuberculosis (TB) typically occurs in apex of lung.
  • ➤ Reactivated tuberculosis

questions.text: All of the following are associated with low complement levels except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diarrhea associated hemolytic uremic syn­drome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Lupus Nephritis: In lupus nephritis, an autoimmune condition where the body's own immune system attacks the kidneys , low complement levels are common due to the consumption of complement in the formation of immune complexes.
  • • Option A: Lupus Nephritis:
  • • autoimmune
  • • body's own immune system
  • • kidneys
  • • low complement levels
  • • consumption of complement
  • • immune complexes.
  • • Option B: Mesangiocapillary Glomerulonephritis: This condition, also known as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, involves the deposition of immune complexes in the mesangium and capillary walls of the kidneys , often leading to persistent low complement levels , particularly C3 , due to the activation of the complement system .
  • • Option B: Mesangiocapillary Glomerulonephritis:
  • • membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis,
  • • immune complexes
  • • mesangium and capillary walls of the kidneys
  • • low complement levels
  • • C3
  • • activation of the complement system
  • • Option D: Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis: This usually occurs after infections such as streptococcal infection . While it can result in transient low complement levels due to immune complex deposition and complement activation , the levels usually return to normal within several weeks .
  • • Option D: Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis:
  • • streptococcal infection
  • • transient low complement levels
  • • immune complex deposition
  • • complement activation
  • • normal within several weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low complement levels are typically associated with conditions involving immune complex deposition and activation of the complement pathway , such as lupus nephritis, mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis, and post-infectious glomerulonephritis. Diarrhea-associated hemolytic uremic syndrome , however, does not commonly involve complement system alterations, setting it apart from other causes of nephritic syndrome with low complement levels .
  • ➤ Low complement levels
  • ➤ immune complex deposition
  • ➤ activation
  • ➤ complement pathway
  • ➤ lupus nephritis, mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis, and post-infectious glomerulonephritis.
  • ➤ Diarrhea-associated hemolytic uremic syndrome
  • ➤ does not
  • ➤ complement system
  • ➤ nephritic syndrome with low complement levels
  • ➤ Nephritic syndrome associated with low C3
  • ➤ Nephritic syndrome associated with low C3
  • ➤ Nephritic syndrome associated with low C3
  • ➤ (Ref: 10 th / 938)
  • ➤ (Ref: 10 th / 938)

questions.text: A patient presents with pruritic jaundice and undergoes abdominal ultrasonography, which reveals a characteristic 'double barrel' sign. Based on this finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. CBD obstruction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A - Cystic Duct Obstruction: This condition often leads to gallbladder distention but would not typically create the double-barrel sign on ultrasound. It can cause symptoms of biliary colic but without the pruritic jaundice unless there is associated cholangitis.
  • • Option A - Cystic Duct Obstruction:
  • • gallbladder distention
  • • create the double-barrel sign on ultrasound.
  • • Option C - Acute Cholecystitis: This is an inflammation of the gallbladder often caused by cystic duct obstruction due to gallstones. Ultrasound may show gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and a positive sonographic Murphy's sign but not the double-barrel sign indicative of a dilated CBD.
  • • Option C - Acute Cholecystitis:
  • • inflammation
  • • gallbladder
  • • cystic duct obstruction due to gallstones.
  • • Option D - Gallbladder Cancer: Cancer of the gallbladder can lead to biliary obstruction, but the double-barrel sign is not a typical ultrasonographic feature. Instead, irregular thickening or a mass in the gallbladder might be seen. Jaundice may occur late in the disease due to bile duct obstruction.
  • • Option D - Gallbladder Cancer:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The double-barrel sign on ultrasound is indicative of CBD obstruction, where the dilated CBD appears as a channel parallel to the portal vein , often leading to pruritic jaundice due to the accumulation of bile.
  • ➤ double-barrel sign
  • ➤ CBD obstruction,
  • ➤ dilated CBD appears as a channel parallel to the portal vein
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 370
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 370

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient sustains a traumatic injury resulting in damage to nervous tissue. The subsequent healing process involves the formation of scar tissue at the site of injury. Which of the following cell types is primarily responsible for the formation of scar tissue during the repair of nervous tissue?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neuroglia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Fibroblasts are the primary cell type responsible for scar formation in peripheral tissues , but not typically within the CNS, as they produce collagen and other extracellular matrix components leading to the formation of connective tissue scars.
  • • Option B: Fibroblasts
  • • primary cell type
  • • scar formation in peripheral tissues
  • • Option C: Axons do not form scar tissue but can be i nvolved in the regeneration process in the peripheral nervous system under certain conditions.
  • • Option C: Axons
  • • nvolved in the regeneration process
  • • peripheral nervous system
  • • Option D: Microglia are the resident macrophages of the CNS , involved in the immune response and clean-up after injury but are not the primary cells responsible for scar tissue formation.
  • • Option D: Microglia
  • • resident macrophages of the CNS
  • • immune response
  • • clean-up after injury
  • • primary cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cell type primarily responsible for the formation of scar tissue during the repair of nervous tissue is Neuroglia , as astrocytes , a type of glial cell , play a crucial role in the gliosis process that leads to scar formation in the CNS .
  • ➤ cell type
  • ➤ formation of scar tissue
  • ➤ repair of nervous tissue is Neuroglia
  • ➤ astrocytes
  • ➤ glial cell
  • ➤ gliosis process
  • ➤ scar formation in the CNS
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1255
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1255

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, abdominal pain, and jaundice. On physical examination, she has hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. Her laboratory tests show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Imaging studies reveal intrahepatic bile duct dilatation as shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Caroli’s disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hepatoma: Also known as hepatocellular carcinoma , is a primary malignancy of the liver . It usually occurs in the setting of chronic liver disease , such as cirrhosis . Imaging might show a solitary liver mass with arterial enhancement and venous washout, but it does not typically present with intrahepatic bile duct dilatation.
  • • Option A. Hepatoma:
  • • hepatocellular carcinoma
  • • primary malignancy
  • • liver
  • • setting of chronic liver disease
  • • cirrhosis
  • • Option B. Hemangioma: Is a common benign liver tumor often found incidentally on imaging . It is characterized by its typical appearance on ultrasound as a hyperechoic lesion and on MRI as a hyperintense lesion on T2-weighted images with peripheral nodular enhancement.
  • • Option B. Hemangioma:
  • • common benign liver tumor
  • • incidentally on imaging
  • • typical appearance on ultrasound
  • • hyperechoic lesion
  • • MRI as a hyperintense lesion
  • • Option D. A Hydatid cyst: Is a parasitic infection caused by Echinococcus granulosus . Imaging usually shows a well-defined cystic structure within the liver, potentially with daughter cysts and calcifications, rather than isolated bile duct dilatation.
  • • Option D. A Hydatid cyst:
  • • parasitic infection
  • • Echinococcus granulosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caroli’s Disease can be identified by central dot sign on imaging , which suggests dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts , and differentiates it from other hepatic lesions such as hepatoma , hemangioma , and hydatid cyst .
  • ➤ Caroli’s Disease
  • ➤ central dot sign on imaging
  • ➤ dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts
  • ➤ hepatic lesions
  • ➤ hepatoma
  • ➤ hemangioma
  • ➤ hydatid cyst
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 364
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 364

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of a blow-out fracture of orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Diplopia : It is a common symptom of blow-out fractures , often resulting from impaired movement of the affected eye due to muscle entrapment or nerve damage.
  • • Option B.
  • • Diplopia
  • • common symptom of blow-out fractures
  • • resulting from impaired movement
  • • Option C. Enophthalmos : This is the posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit , leading to a sunken appearance. It is a characteristic sign of blow-out fractures. The increase in the orbital volume caused by the fracture allows the eyeball to sink backward.
  • • Option C.
  • • Enophthalmos
  • • posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit
  • • sunken appearance.
  • • Option D. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia : This refers to a loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve , typically the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip . It can occur in blow-out fractures if the fracture involves the infraorbital groove or canal, where the nerve runs.
  • • Option D.
  • • Infraorbital nerve anesthesia
  • • loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve
  • • lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos , is a sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit . Blow-out fractures typically increase orbital volume , allowing the eyeball to sink backward , leading to enophthalmos , rather than protruding forward as in exophthalmos.
  • ➤ Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos
  • ➤ sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit
  • ➤ increase orbital volume
  • ➤ eyeball to sink backward
  • ➤ enophthalmos
  • ➤ protruding forward as in exophthalmos.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 864 kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 864 kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with headaches and visual disturbances. Imaging reveals a suprasellar mass consistent with a craniopharyngioma. The patient is concerned about the potential spread of the tumor. Which of the following brain tumors is least likely to spread via cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Germ cell tumors, particularly those occurring in the brain , can disseminate via the CSF due to their typical midline location, which facilitates spread through the ventricular system.
  • • Option A: Germ cell tumors,
  • • occurring in the brain
  • • Option B: Medulloblastoma is a highly malignant primary brain tumor that often spreads via the CSF , characteristically leading to drop metastasis at the cauda equina.
  • • Option B: Medulloblastoma
  • • highly malignant primary brain tumor
  • • spreads via the CSF
  • • Option C: CNS lymphoma , although primarily a parenchymal brain tumor , can occasionally disseminate in the CSF , particularly in the setting of leptomeningeal disease.
  • • Option C: CNS lymphoma
  • • parenchymal brain tumor
  • • disseminate in the CSF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopharyngioma is the brain tumor that is least likely to spread via cerebrospinal fluid , as it typically presents with local growth and does not commonly disseminate through the CSF pathways.
  • ➤ Craniopharyngioma
  • ➤ brain tumor
  • ➤ least likely to spread via cerebrospinal fluid
  • ➤ presents with local growth
  • ➤ Brain tumors spreading via CSF are
  • ➤ Brain tumors spreading via CSF are
  • ➤ Ependymoma Medulloblastoma Choroid plexus carcinoma Astrocytoma Germinoma Pineoblastoma CNS Lymphoma.
  • ➤ Ependymoma
  • ➤ Medulloblastoma
  • ➤ Choroid plexus carcinoma
  • ➤ Astrocytoma
  • ➤ Germinoma
  • ➤ Pineoblastoma
  • ➤ CNS Lymphoma.
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th/ 1293
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th/ 1293

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who regularly wears contact lenses came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of severe pain in right eye along with redness and blurring of vision since the past few days. Her eye is shown below. Which of the following given options can be considered for her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chlorhexidine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cefazolin is a cephalosporin antibiotic used against a range of bacterial infections. However, it is not effective against Acanthamoeba and is not used in the treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • • Option A.
  • • cephalosporin antibiotic
  • • Option C. Tobramycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic . While it is effective against various bacterial infections and is commonly used in treating bacterial keratitis , it is not effective against Acanthamoeba.
  • • Option C.
  • • aminoglycoside antibiotic
  • • treating bacterial keratitis
  • • Option D. Voriconazole is an antifungal medication . While it has a broad spectrum of activity , its use in Acanthamoeba keratitis is more limited. It may be considered in certain cases, particularly for fungal co-infections , but it's not a first-line treatment for Acanthamoeba.
  • • Option D.
  • • antifungal medication
  • • broad spectrum
  • • activity
  • • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • • fungal co-infections

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For the treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis, chlorhexidine is considered effective and is commonly used, as opposed to antibiotics like cefazolin and tobramycin or antifungals like voriconazole, which are not primarily effective against this protozoan infection.
  • ➤ considered effective
  • ➤ opposed
  • ➤ antibiotics
  • ➤ cefazolin
  • ➤ tobramycin
  • ➤ antifungals
  • ➤ Ref : KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 232
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 232

questions.text: Identify the abnormality:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Morning glory syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. OPTIC DISC PIT: An optic disc pit is a congenital anomaly characterized by a small, round or oval, grayish depression in the optic nerve head , often associated with potential complications like serous macular detachment.
  • • Option A. OPTIC DISC PIT:
  • • congenital anomaly characterized by a small, round or oval, grayish depression in the optic nerve head
  • • Option B: Posterior staphyloma: Posterior staphyloma is a localized protrusion or bulging of the sclera (the white outer layer of the eye) at the back of the eye , often associated with severe myopia (nearsightedness) and thinning of the scleral tissue.
  • • Option B: Posterior staphyloma:
  • • localized protrusion or bulging of the sclera
  • • back of the eye
  • • associated with severe myopia
  • • Option D. Advanced glaucomatous cupping: Advanced glaucomatous cupping refers to the deepening and enlargement of the optic cup in the optic nerve head , a sign of progressive damage caused by glaucoma , leading to a distinctive cup-to-disc ratio increase and corresponding vision loss.
  • • Option D. Advanced glaucomatous cupping:
  • • deepening and enlargement of the optic cup in the optic nerve head
  • • progressive damage caused by glaucoma
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Morning Glory Syndrome is a congenital, enlarged, funnel-shaped optic disc anomaly.
  • • Morning Glory Syndrome
  • • congenital, enlarged, funnel-shaped optic disc anomaly.
  • • REF : KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 774
  • • REF :
  • • KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 774

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of intermittent tearing from her left eye. Examination reveals no significant eye redness or visual impairment. She mentions the symptoms are more pronounced in windy conditions or when she is tired. Further examination of the eyelid function reveals a slight delay in tear drainage. Which part of the orbicularis oculi muscle, involved in tear drainage and commonly affected in such cases, is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lacrimal (Horner’s muscle)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Orbital Part : This part of the orbicularis oculi muscle is involved in the forceful closure of the eyelids , as in blinking . It's not directly involved in tear drainage.
  • • Option A.
  • • Orbital Part
  • • orbicularis oculi muscle
  • • forceful closure of the eyelids
  • • blinking
  • • Option B. Temporal Part : This is not a distinct part of the orbicularis oculi muscle ; rather, the muscle has palpebral and orbital parts . The temporal part does not relate to tear drainage.
  • • Option B.
  • • Temporal Part
  • • not a distinct part of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • • muscle has palpebral and orbital parts
  • • Option D. Muller’s Muscle : Muller's muscle, or the superior tarsal muscle , is a smooth muscle that contributes to eyelid elevation . It is not a part of the orbicularis oculi muscle and does not influence tear drainage.
  • • Option D.
  • • Muller’s Muscle
  • • superior tarsal muscle
  • • smooth muscle
  • • contributes to eyelid elevation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Horner’s muscle refers to the lacrimal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle , which is integral in tear drainage.
  • ➤ Horner’s muscle
  • ➤ lacrimal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • ➤ integral in tear drainage.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 492/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 492/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Function of hepatic stellate cells is/are:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin A storage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Hepatic sinusoids are specialized blood vessels within the liver that facilitate exchange between the blood and hepatocytes . Sinusoid formation involves complex interactions between various cell types during liver development.
  • • Option A:
  • • Hepatic sinusoids
  • • specialized blood vessels
  • • liver
  • • facilitate exchange between the blood
  • • hepatocytes
  • • Option C: Hepatic stellate cells do not directly regulate blood perfusion in the liver . Blood perfusion within the liver is primarily regulated by hepatic blood flow dynamics , which involve interactions between hepatic arteries, portal veins, and hepatic sinusoids.
  • • Option C:
  • • Hepatic stellate cells
  • • not directly regulate blood perfusion
  • • liver
  • • Blood perfusion
  • • liver
  • • regulated by hepatic blood flow dynamics
  • • Option D: Phagocytic activity in the liver is primarily carried out by Kupffer cells , which are specialized macrophages located within the hepatic sinusoids . Kupffer cells play a crucial role in clearing pathogens, cellular debris, and foreign particles from the bloodstream, contributing to liver defense and immune function.
  • • Option D:
  • • Phagocytic activity
  • • liver
  • • carried out by Kupffer cells
  • • specialized macrophages
  • • hepatic sinusoids
  • • Educational objective:
