questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a painful left shoulder and a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Examination reveals a swollen and tender shoulder joint with limited range of motion. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the leukocyte migration to the affected joint?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chemotaxis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Increased vascular permeability allows for the extravasation of fluid and cells from the circulation into the tissues . This is a vital part of the inflammatory response that leads to edema . However, while it facilitates the movement of leukocytes out of the capillaries, it is not the mechanism that specifically directs their migration to the site of inflammation.
  • • Option A. Increased vascular permeability
  • • extravasation of fluid and cells from the circulation into the tissues
  • • inflammatory response
  • • edema
  • • movement of leukocytes out of the
  • • capillaries,
  • • Option B. Vasodilation , the widening of blood vessels , is mediated by various inflammatory mediators and leads to increased blood flow. This process causes the classic signs of redness and warmth but does not specifically direct leukocytes to the site of inflammation.
  • • Option B. Vasodilation
  • • widening of blood vessels
  • • inflammatory mediators
  • • leads to increased blood flow.
  • • classic signs of redness and warmth
  • • direct leukocytes to the site of inflammation.
  • • Option D. Opsonization involves the tagging of pathogens with molecules such as antibodies or complement proteins that enhance their uptake by phagocytes. It is an essential process in the immune response to pathogens but does not involve the migration of leukocytes to the site of inflammation.
  • • Option D. Opsonization
  • • tagging of pathogens
  • • antibodies or complement proteins
  • • phagocytes.
  • • essential process in the immune response

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chemotaxis is the mechanism that drives leukocytes to migrate to the affected joint in rheumatoid arthritis , guided by chemokines and cytokines produced in response to the inflammatory process.
  • ➤ Chemotaxis
  • ➤ drives leukocytes to migrate to the affected joint in rheumatoid arthritis
  • ➤ chemokines and cytokines
  • ➤ inflammatory process.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to the emergency department with a two-day history of nausea, vomiting and periumbilical and lower abdominal pain. She experienced fever also earlier in the day. Physical exam showed local tenderness and rigidity with rebound pain in the lower abdomen. Laboratory tests revealed leucoytosis and elevated ESR and C-reactive protein. She underwent an exploratory laparotomy. The pain experienced by this patient is MOST LIKELY the result of the formation of which of the following two chemical mediators?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin and bradykinin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Complement C3b is a part of the complement system , which enhances the ability of antibodies and phagocytic cells to clear microbes and damaged cells, promote inflammation, and attack the pathogen's cell membrane. IgG is an antibody isotype that plays a crucial role in the immune response by binding to pathogens and marking them for destruction . While both are integral to the immune response and opsonization, they are not directly associated with the sensation of pain.
  • • Option A. Complement C3b
  • • complement system
  • • antibodies and phagocytic cells to clear microbes and damaged cells, promote inflammation,
  • • cell membrane. IgG
  • • immune response by binding to pathogens and marking them for destruction
  • • immune response and opsonization,
  • • not
  • • sensation of pain.
  • • Option B. IL-1 and TNF are cytokines that play a central role in the regulation of immune and inflammatory responses . IL-1 induces fever and the production of other cytokines , while TNF has a wide range of pro-inflammatory effects, including the activation of endothelial cells and leukocytes . They can indirectly contribute to pain by promoting the inflammatory process , but they are not the primary chemical mediators directly responsible for pain sensation.
  • • Option B.
  • • IL-1 and TNF
  • • cytokines
  • • immune and inflammatory responses
  • • IL-1
  • • fever
  • • other cytokines
  • • TNF
  • • pro-inflammatory effects,
  • • activation of
  • • endothelial cells and leukocytes
  • • pain by promoting the inflammatory process
  • • Option C. Histamine is released by mast cells and plays a role in the local immune response to foreign pathogens . It causes dilation of the capillaries, contraction of smooth muscle, and increased gastric acid secretion , leading to symptoms like swelling, redness, and itching . Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that can modulate mood and pain perception centrally, but peripherally, it can contribute to vasoconstriction and blood clotting . While both histamine and serotonin contribute to inflammation and can cause discomfort, they are not the main mediators for pain in acute inflammation.
  • • Option C. Histamine
  • • mast cells
  • • local immune response to foreign pathogens
  • • dilation of the capillaries, contraction of smooth muscle, and increased gastric acid secretion
  • • swelling, redness, and itching
  • • Serotonin
  • • neurotransmitter
  • • mood and pain perception
  • • vasoconstriction and blood clotting
  • • both histamine and serotonin contribute to inflammation

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old individual presents to the clinic with sudden-onset severe eye redness, copious purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling.   • • Chlamydia
  • • inclusion conjunctivitis
  • • sexually active young adults
  • • more subacute
  • • chronic
  • • Option D. Adenovirus is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis , often leading to watery discharge , irritation , and conjunctival redness . However, adenoviral infections do not typically cause the severe purulent discharge or the marked eyelid swelling seen in gonococcal conjunctivitis.

  • • viral conjunctivitis

  • • irritation
  • • conjunctival redness

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a genetic anomaly affecting the activity of disaccharidases produced by the intestinal epithelial cells. questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with numbness and tingling in his hands and feet. He also reports weakness and difficulty walking. Examination reveals enlarged tongue, carpal tunnel syndrome, and a waddling gait. Biopsy of the sural nerve shows deposits of amyloid protein. Which of the following is not correct about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Congo red is the commonest stain used for diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: Electron microscopy shows non branching fibrils

options.label: D
options.text: Apple green birefringence with PAS staining

questions.correct_answer: D. Apple green birefringence with PAS staining
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Apple green birefringence with PAS staining

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Congo red staining is indeed the most common method used for the diagnosis of amyloidosis . When viewed under polarized light, amyloid deposits stained with Congo red show a characteristic apple green birefringence.
  • • Option A.
  • • Congo red staining
  • • diagnosis of amyloidosis
  • • polarized light, amyloid deposits
  • • apple green birefringence.
  • • Option B. Electron microscopy of amyloid fibrils typically shows non-branching, linear fibrils . This is due to the beta-pleated sheet configuration of the proteins that make up the fibrils , which is a hallmark of amyloid deposits .
  • • Option B.
  • • Electron microscopy of amyloid fibrils
  • • non-branching, linear fibrils
  • • due to the beta-pleated sheet configuration
  • • make up the fibrils
  • • hallmark of amyloid deposits
  • • Option C. On spectroscopy , the beta-pleated sheet conformation of the amyloid fibrils results in a distinct pattern . This structure is stable and resistant to proteolysis , which is why amyloid deposits are typically insoluble and accumulate in various tissues.
  • • Option C.
  • • On spectroscopy
  • • beta-pleated sheet
  • • amyloid fibrils
  • • distinct pattern
  • • stable and resistant to proteolysis
  • • insoluble

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amyloid deposits do not exhibit apple green birefringence when stained with PAS; this characteristic is observed with Congo red staining under polarized light.
  • ➤ Apple green birefringence is seen with Congo red under polarised light
  • ➤ Apple green birefringence is seen with Congo red under polarised light
  • ➤ Robbins 10 th /259
  • ➤ Robbins 10 th /259

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with diffuse back pain. Upon examination, there is no limitation of motion in the sacroiliac joints, and the intervertebral disc spaces appear preserved. The cervical spine X-ray reveals flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspects of the vertebral bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. DISH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton , leading to the fusion of affected joints , known as ankylosis . The hallmark radiographic findings in AS are sacroiliitis and syndesmophytes , leading to a "bamboo spine" appearance . However, the intervertebral disc spaces are typically preserved until late in the disease.
  • • Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis:
  • • affects the sacroiliac joints
  • • axial skeleton
  • • fusion of affected joints
  • • ankylosis
  • • radiographic findings
  • • AS are sacroiliitis
  • • syndesmophytes
  • • "bamboo spine" appearance
  • • Option C. Klippel-Feil Syndrome: Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae . It may present with a short neck, limited neck movement, and low hairline. Radiographs would show fused cervical vertebrae, but not the flowing ossifications typical of DISH.
  • • Option C. Klippel-Feil Syndrome:
  • • congenital condition
  • • fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae
  • • Option D. Sprengel Deformity: Sprengel deformity is a congenital condition in which the scapula is abnormally high due to its failure to descend during development . It's not related to spinal pathology and wouldn't show the characteristic findings of DISH on spinal imaging.
  • • Option D. Sprengel Deformity:
  • • congenital condition
  • • scapula is abnormally high
  • • failure to descend during development

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The X-ray findings of flowing ossification along the anterior aspects of the thoracic spine with preserved intervertebral disc spaces in an elderly patient is indicative of DISH , which does not involve the sacroiliac joints.
  • ➤ X-ray findings of flowing ossification
  • ➤ anterior aspects of the thoracic spine
  • ➤ preserved intervertebral disc spaces
  • ➤ DISH
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 616
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 616

  • • separate chorions
  • • share a single amniotic sac
  • • Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both the chorionic and amniotic sacs , presenting a high-risk situation with no intervening membrane.

  • • both the chorionic and amniotic sacs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The ultrasound shows the 'twin peak' or lambda (λ) sign , which is characteristic of dichorionic diamniotic twins . This signifies that each twin has its own chorionic and amniotic sac, the most common and least complicated type of twin pregnancy.

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to the risk of gastrointestinal perforation and worsening respiratory distress.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female presents with dysphagia, especially with solid foods, and has noted a burning sensation in her tongue. She reports a history of fatigue and breathlessness on exertion. On examination, her tongue is smooth and atrophic, and laboratory tests reveal a microcytic anemia. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

Explanation:

  • • Option A. Glossitis: Correctly associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome , representing the smooth, atrophic tongue observed in this patient.
  • • Option A. Glossitis:
  • • Plummer-Vinson syndrome
  • • smooth, atrophic tongue
  • • Option B. Esophageal webs: Also correctly associated, potentially explaining the patient's dysphagia for solids .
  • • Option B. Esophageal webs:
  • • patient's dysphagia for solids
  • • Option D. Esophageal dysphagia: Correctly associated, as this symptom is often due to esophageal webs or strictures present in Plummer-Vinson syndrome .
  • • Option D. Esophageal dysphagia:
  • • due to esophageal webs or strictures
  • • Plummer-Vinson syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical features of Plummer-Vinson syndrome , include glossitis, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs, and differentiate it from megaloblastic anemia.
  • ➤ Plummer-Vinson syndrome
  • ➤ glossitis, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs,
  • ➤ Plummer-Vinson syndrome, also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome, is characterized by the triad of glossitis, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs . So, the correct answer is (c) Megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding reversible cell injury, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

questions.correct_answer: A. Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix is typically associated with irreversible cell injury rather than reversible cell injury. This change indicates severe damage to the mitochondria, often due to sustained injury that compromises mitochondrial function beyond the cell's ability to recover.
  • • Other Options Explained:
  • • Other Options Explained:
  • • Option B. Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) : This is characteristic of reversible cell injury. It occurs due to temporary impairment of mitochondrial function, which can recover if the injurious stimulus is removed. Option C. Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane : Blebbing is a response to reversible cell injury. It involves changes in the cytoskeleton and plasma membrane, which can be restored once the injury ceases. Option D. Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum : This change can occur during reversible cell injury and reflects a temporary disruption in protein synthesis. If the injury is mild and transient, normal ribosomal function can resume.
  • • Option B. Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) : This is characteristic of reversible cell injury. It occurs due to temporary impairment of mitochondrial function, which can recover if the injurious stimulus is removed.
  • • Option B. Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
  • • Option C. Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane : Blebbing is a response to reversible cell injury. It involves changes in the cytoskeleton and plasma membrane, which can be restored once the injury ceases.
  • • Option C. Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane
  • • Option D. Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum : This change can occur during reversible cell injury and reflects a temporary disruption in protein synthesis. If the injury is mild and transient, normal ribosomal function can resume.
  • • Option D. Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amorphous densities in mitochondria are a hallmark of irreversible injury, while diminished ATP production, membrane blebbing, and ribosome detachment are associated with reversible cell injury

questions.text: Joint erosion is not a feature in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Gout. Gout is characterized by the deposition of urate crystals in joints, leading to inflammation. If left untreated and chronic, gout can cause joint damage and erosion over time.
  • • Option B. Gout.
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis. Joint erosion is a prominent feature of rheumatoid arthritis. Chronic inflammation in RA can lead to the destruction of cartilage and bone in affected joints.
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option D. Psoriasis. Psoriatic arthritis, associated with psoriasis, can cause joint damage, including joint erosion. Joint involvement in psoriatic arthritis may lead to erosive changes similar to those seen in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option D. Psoriasis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While joint involvement can occur in SLE, erosive changes are generally less common compared to conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or psoriatic arthritis.
  • ➤ While joint involvement can occur in SLE, erosive changes are generally less common compared to conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of type I diabetes mellitus has been diligently adhering to insulin therapy, yet consistently records fasting and postprandial blood glucose levels that exceed the normal range. To assist in better glucose regulation, a dietician suggests an increased intake of dietary fiber. Among the Option listed below, which type of dietary fiber is most beneficial for managing blood glucose levels in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Pectin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Cellulose : These are polymers of glucose. It retains water in feces; promotes peristalsis and increases bowel action. It is the starting material for production of fibres, celluloids, nitrocellulose, and plastics.
  • • Option A: Cellulose
  • • Option B: Hemicellulose : These include pentoses, hexoses and uronic acid, which retains water in feces and increases bile acid excretion.
  • • Option B: Hemicellulose
  • • Option C: Lignin : They are aromatic alcohols with hypocholesterolemic, antioxidant action and also increases bile acid excretion.
  • • Option C: Lignin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dietary fibers are classified as soluble (pectin, gums, mucilages) or insoluble (cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin). Soluble fibers like pectin form viscous gels that slow digestion and absorption of carbohydrates, making them particularly beneficial for blood glucose management in diabetes. Pectin is found in fruits (especially apples, citrus fruits), berries, and some vegetables. Insoluble fibers primarily improve bowel health and regularity without significantly affecting blood glucose levels directly.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: P 156-158.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: This fundus appearance is seen in which form of refractive error?

Explanation:

questions.text: A patient with open wound with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Open wound with fracture with wound <1 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury

options.label: C
options.text: Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required

options.label: D
options.text: Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.correct_answer: D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Open wound with fracture with wound < 1cm . This is type 1 of the Gustilo-Anderson classification where the wound is < 1cm in size and is a clear wound.
  • • Option A. Open wound with fracture with wound < 1cm
  • • Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury . This is type 2 of the Gustilo-Anderson classification where the wound size is > 1cm without any extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap or avulsion.
  • • Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
  • • Option C. Open wound > 10cm, though soft tissue coverage not required . This is the type 3A where there is adequate periosteal coverage present.
  • • Option C. Open wound > 10cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The type 3B of the open fracture involves significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap. The wound size is > 10cm in this type.
  • • The type 3B of the open fracture involves significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap.
  • • The wound size is > 10cm in this type.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient reported with complaints of blurring of vision in his left eye for the past 2 weeks. He had a past history of central retinal vein occlusion in the left eye, which was diagnosed almost 3 months back. Slit lamp examination revealed rubeosis iridis in all the four quadrants. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in left eye is 72 mm of Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

  • • increased IOP
  • • Option C. Posner-Schlossman Syndrome, also known as Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis , this condition typically presents with mild elevation of IOP and not with rubeosis iridis. It's characterized by recurrent attacks of mild inflammation and elevated IOP .

  • • Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis

  • • IOP

  • • mild inflammation
  • • elevated IOP

This condition is often a consequence of ischemic retinal diseases and presents with new blood vessel formation on the iris and angle , leading to increased intraocular pressure due to impaired aqueous humor drainage .

questions.text: At her 27-week prenatal check-up in a Mumbai healthcare clinic, a pregnant woman receives a rubella vaccine. Subsequently, her body develops anti-rubella antibodies. questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gene rearrangement

  • • mechanism

  • • E.g
  • • (
  • • Option C. Alternate splicing: Tissue-specific protein isoforms can be made from the same pre-mRNA through differential co-transcriptional processing , especially the use of alternative splice sites . e.g: Tropomyosin (TM), its pre-mRNA undergoes tissue-specific differential splicing to yield different TM isoforms.

  • • Tissue-specific protein isoforms
  • • made from the same pre-mRNA
  • • differential co-transcriptional processing
  • • . e.g:
  • • Option D. RNA interference: It is a mechanism of gene silencing with decreased expression of mRNA , either by repression of translation or by increased degradation . E.g: It plays a key role in fundamental processes as cell proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis.

  • • mechanism of gene silencing
  • • decreased expression of mRNA

This mechanism involves the reorganization of variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments in B cells . This recombination leads to a vast diversity of antibodies, enabling the immune system to recognize a wide array of antigens, such as those presented by the rubella virus following vaccination.

questions.text: When light is flashed onto one eye, both the eyes’ pupils constrict as a response. This is known as the pupillary light reflex. Where is the center for this reflex located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Midbrain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A : Pons : Pontine centres are involved in optokinetic nystagmus . Pontine lesions cause dolls eye movement.
  • • Option A
  • • Pons
  • • Pontine centres
  • • optokinetic nystagmus
  • • dolls eye movement.
  • • Option D: Cerebellum - Cerebellum is involved in integration and coordination of optokinetic nystagmus . Characteristics of cerebellar nystagmus include:
  • • Option D: Cerebellum
  • • integration and coordination of optokinetic nystagmus
  • • Direction : It is typically horizontal, but can also be vertical or rotary. The direction of the nystagmus may change depending on the direction of gaze. Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus : This form of nystagmus becomes more pronounced when the patient looks to the side. It is due to the failure of the cerebellum to hold steady gaze, leading to a drift of the eyes back to the central position, followed by a corrective saccade. Intensity and Amplitude : The intensity and amplitude of the nystagmus can increase with the degree of lateral gaze and decrease or disappear with gaze towards the midline. Associated Symptoms : Patients with cerebellar nystagmus may also exhibit other signs of cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia, dysarthria, and tremor.
  • • Direction : It is typically horizontal, but can also be vertical or rotary. The direction of the nystagmus may change depending on the direction of gaze.

  • • Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus
  • • Intensity and Amplitude : The intensity and amplitude of the nystagmus can increase with the degree of lateral gaze and decrease or disappear with gaze towards the midline.
  • • Intensity and Amplitude
  • • Associated Symptoms : Patients with cerebellar nystagmus may also exhibit other signs of cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia, dysarthria, and tremor.

questions.text: A radiology resident is reviewing a thyroid ultrasound for evaluation of a nodule. Which of the following is NOT included in the American College of Radiology's Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System (ACR TI-RADS) criteria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Vascularity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Margin: Margins are evaluated in thyroid nodules to determine the risk of malignancy . TI-RADS includes margin assessment with descriptors like smooth, ill-defined, lobulated, or irregular to score the nodules.
  • • Option A: Margin:
  • • evaluated in thyroid nodules
  • • risk of malignancy
  • • Option B: Echogenicity: Echogenicity describes the brightness of a thyroid nodule compared to the surrounding thyroid tissue . TI-RADS uses echogenicity as a criterion, including anechoic, hyperechoic, isoechoic, and hypoechoic as descriptors.
  • • Option B: Echogenicity:
  • • brightness of a thyroid nodule
  • • surrounding thyroid tissue
  • • Option D: Shape: The shape of a nodule , whether it is wider than tall or taller-than-wide , is a significant factor in TI-RADS. A taller-than-wide shape is more concerning for malignancy and is thus included in the TI-RADS scoring system.
  • • Option D: Shape:
  • • nodule
  • • wider than tall
  • • taller-than-wide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vascularity is not included in the ACR TI-RADS criteria for thyroid nodules. TI-RADS is utilized to stratify the risk of thyroid nodules based on their ultrasound characteristics , excluding vascularity , which aids medical students and residents in identifying nodules that may require further evaluation or intervention.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of chronic gastritis presents with weight loss and early satiety. An endoscopy with biopsy is performed, revealing a 2 cm lesion in the antrum of the stomach. Histopathology reports a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Additional staining shows the cancer is confined to the gastric wall with no evidence of metastasis. In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy is confined to which of the following layers?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mucosa and submucosa

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. If a gastric carcinoma is confined to the mucosa , it indicates that the tumor has not penetrated beyond the innermost layer of the stomach , which is associated with a less aggressive disease and often a more favorable prognosis.
  • • Option A.
  • • confined to the mucosa
  • • tumor has not penetrated beyond the innermost layer of the stomach
  • • less aggressive disease
  • • Option C. Penetration into the muscularis propria denotes a more advanced local invasion compared to options A and B, suggesting a higher risk of further spread and a worse prognosis if not treated promptly.
  • • Option C. Penetration into the muscularis propria
  • • more advanced local invasion
  • • higher risk
  • • spread and a worse prognosis
  • • not treated promptly.
  • • Option D. Invasion of the serosa , the outermost layer of the stomach , implies that the tumor may be at the stage where it is capable of spreading beyond the stomach to adjacent structures or through the peritoneal surface , which would denote a more advanced and aggressive disease.
  • • Option D.
  • • Invasion of the serosa
  • • outermost layer of the stomach
  • • capable of spreading beyond the stomach to adjacent structures or through the peritoneal surface
  • • denote a more advanced and aggressive disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy confined to the mucosa and submucosa signifies a depth of invasion that is more advanced than the mucosal layer alone , but not yet extending into the muscularis propria or serosa .
  • ➤ early gastric carcinoma,
  • ➤ mucosa and submucosa
  • ➤ depth of invasion
  • ➤ more advanced than the mucosal layer alone
  • ➤ not yet
  • ➤ muscularis propria or serosa

questions.text: A patient with Burkitt lymphoma presents with lethargy, weakness, and oliguria after receiving the first cycle of chemotherapy. Laboratory tests reveal abnormalities consistent with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). Which of the following laboratory findings is LEAST likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypercalcemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanations
  • • Option A. Hyperuricemia is typically seen in TLS due to the increased turnover of nucleic acids from rapid cell lysis , leading to excess production of uric acid .
  • • Option A.
  • • Hyperuricemia
  • • TLS
  • • increased
  • • nucleic acids from rapid cell lysis
  • • uric acid
  • • Option B. Hyperkalemia results from the release of potassium , the most abundant intracellular cation , into the bloodstream when cells lyse .
  • • Option B.
  • • Hyperkalemia
  • • release of potassium
  • • intracellular cation
  • • bloodstream
  • • cells lyse
  • • Option C. Hyperphosphatemia occurs due to the release of intracellular phosphate into the extracellular fluid during cell lysis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Hyperphosphatemia
  • • intracellular phosphate into the extracellular fluid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumor lysis syndrome is characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia, but not hypercalcemia ; instead, hypocalcemia occurs due to the complexing of calcium with elevated phosphate levels .
  • ➤ Tumor lysis
  • ➤ hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia,
  • ➤ not hypercalcemia
  • ➤ hypocalcemia
  • ➤ complexing of calcium with elevated phosphate levels

questions.text: A couple with a 5-year-old son diagnosed with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is expecting another child. The mother, currently pregnant, is concerned about her unborn daughter potentially having the same condition, despite both parents being clinically unaffected. Considering the genetic nature of G6PD deficiency, which of the following statements is true regarding the risk to the female fetus?

options.label: A
options.text: The baby has a 25% chance of clinical disease

options.label: B
options.text: The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier

options.label: C
options.text: The baby will be a carrier

options.label: D
options.text: The baby has a 50% chance of clinical disease

questions.correct_answer: B. The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. The baby has a 50% chance of being a carrier

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder. Here's how the inheritance works:
  • • Males (XY): If they inherit the defective X chromosome, they express the disease because they have only one X. Females (XX): Need two defective X chromosomes to express the disease. If they inherit one defective X, they are typically carriers.
  • • Males (XY): If they inherit the defective X chromosome, they express the disease because they have only one X.
  • • Males (XY):
  • • Females (XX): Need two defective X chromosomes to express the disease. If they inherit one defective X, they are typically carriers.
  • • Females (XX):
  • • In this scenario:
  • • In this scenario:
  • • The son is affected, meaning he must have inherited the defective X chromosome from his mother. Both parents are clinically unaffected, so: The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • The son is affected, meaning he must have inherited the defective X chromosome from his mother.
  • • Both parents are clinically unaffected, so: The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • The mother is likely a carrier (XᴺXᴰ), and
  • • The father is normal (XᴺY).
  • • When a carrier mother (XᴺXᴰ) and a normal father (XᴺY) have a daughter, the daughter has:
  • • 50% chance of being a carrier (XᴺXᴰ) 50% chance of being completely normal (XᴺXᴺ)
  • • 50% chance of being a carrier (XᴺXᴰ)
  • • 50% chance of being completely normal (XᴺXᴺ)
  • • Thus, the risk to the female fetus is 50% chance of being a carrier.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 25% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. A female would need two defective X chromosomes to be affected, which isn't the case here. Option C. The baby will be a carrier : Incorrect. There’s a 50% chance, not 100%. Option D. 50% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. Females are typically only carriers unless both X chromosomes are defective.
  • • Option A. 25% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. A female would need two defective X chromosomes to be affected, which isn't the case here.
  • • Option A. 25% chance of clinical disease
  • • Option C. The baby will be a carrier : Incorrect. There’s a 50% chance, not 100%.
  • • Option C. The baby will be a carrier
  • • Option D. 50% chance of clinical disease : Incorrect. Females are typically only carriers unless both X chromosomes are defective.
  • • Option D. 50% chance of clinical disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency is the most common enzyme deficiency leading to hemolytic anemia. It affects the pentose phosphate pathway, reducing the production of NADPH, which is essential for maintaining reduced glutathione that protects cells from oxidative damage. This condition predominantly affects males, while female carriers are usually asymptomatic.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 693-694.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient came to ER with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. CTA was performed which is given below. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: An abscess in the psoas muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer: A ruptured gastric ulcer typically presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back . On imaging, especially CT , we might see evidence of perforation with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum). This finding is not consistent with the provided CTA image.
  • • Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer:
  • • presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain
  • • radiate to the back
  • • especially CT
  • • perforation with free air
  • • diaphragm
  • • Option C. Acute appendicitis : Patients with acute appendicitis typically present with abdominal pain that begins around the navel and later localizes to the lower right abdomen , accompanied by fever and leukocytosis . A CTA would show an enlarged, inflamed appendix, potentially with an appendicolith (a calcified deposit), but no contrast extravasation outside the aorta as seen in the provided image.
  • • Option C. Acute appendicitis
  • • abdominal pain
  • • begins around the navel
  • • localizes to the lower right abdomen
  • • fever and leukocytosis
  • • enlarged, inflamed appendix,
  • • appendicolith
  • • Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle: A psoas abscess would typically present with flank pain , fever , and a palpable mass , or difficulty with movements that involve the psoas muscle . On CTA, an abscess may appear as a well-defined fluid collection with possible enhancement after contrast administration. Again, this does not match the findings in the CTA image provided.
  • • Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle:
  • • psoas abscess
  • • present with flank pain
  • • fever
  • • palpable mass
  • • difficulty with movements
  • • psoas muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The correct diagnosis is B - A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The provided CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta , indicative of extraluminal contrast from a ruptured aortic aneurysm . This is an urgent surgical emergency requiring immediate attention.

  • ➤ contrast visible

  • ➤ abdominal aorta
  • ➤ extraluminal contrast
  • ➤ ruptured aortic aneurysm

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a non-healing ulcer on his left foot. Biopsy reveals the presence of granulomas on histological examination. Which of the following diseases is most likely to be associated with this finding?

Skin involvement in sarcoidosis can occur, and while sarcoidosis can cause skin lesions , they do not typically present as non-healing ulcers.

  • • multisystem inflammatory disease

  • • sarcoidosis can cause skin lesions
  • • do not
  • • non-healing ulcers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty swallowing for the past few months. He reports feeling as if food is getting stuck in his chest and he has to drink liquids to help it go down. He also reports regurgitation of undigested food and occasional chest pain. He denies any weight loss, heartburn, or reflux symptoms. On examination, his vital signs are within normal limits, and he appears well-nourished. Auscultation of the lungs is clear, and there are no abdominal masses or hepatosplenomegaly. A barium swallow study is ordered, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Achalasia cardia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Diffuse esophageal spasm would show a corkscrew appearance on imaging, not seen here.
  • • Option A:
  • • Diffuse esophageal spasm
  • • corkscrew appearance
  • • Option B: A hiatus hernia would show a protrusion of the stomach through the diaphragm into the thorax .
  • • Option B:
  • • hiatus hernia
  • • protrusion
  • • stomach
  • • diaphragm
  • • thorax
  • • Option D: Carcinoma of the esophagus usually shows as an irregular narrowing or a stricture , commonly with a "rat-tail" appearance , which is not apparent in this image.
  • • Option D:
  • • Carcinoma
  • • esophagus
  • • irregular narrowing
  • • stricture
  • • "rat-tail" appearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The barium swallow study demonstrates a "bird-beak" sign , indicating achalasia cardia , a condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax and the absence of normal esophageal peristalsis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of left lower quadrant abdominal pain that has been present for several days. He also reports constipation, bloating, and occasional rectal bleeding. On examination, there is tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the likely diagnosis based on his barium enema?
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Option B:

  • • plain abdominal X-ray
  • • "coffee bean"

  • • Sigmoid diverticulitis
  • • fever, leukocytosis
  • • localized abdominal pain
  • • imaging
  • • Option D: Colorectal cancer would typically present with a change in bowel habits , rectal bleeding , and possible mass on digital rectal examination or imaging. Which of the following condition shows ‘Saw tooth appearance’ on abdominal barium enema X-ray.
  • • Option D:
  • • Colorectal cancer
  • • change in bowel habits
  • • rectal bleeding
  • • mass on digital rectal
  • • ‘Saw tooth appearance’ on abdominal barium enema X-ray.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Sigmoid diverticulosis is characterized by the presence of multiple diverticula seen in the sigmoid colon on barium enema imaging , consistent with the symptoms and the X-ray findings shown for the patient. This condition is associated with symptoms like constipation , bloating , and occasional rectal bleeding .

questions.text: Best site for taking biopsy for viral esophagitis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Edge of ulcer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Base of ulcer : This site is preferred for Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. CMV infects the endothelial and stromal cells , and these infected cells are usually found at the base of the ulcer .
  • • Option B. Base of ulcer
  • • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections.
  • • endothelial and stromal cells
  • • infected cells
  • • at the base of the ulcer
  • • Option C. Adjacent indurated area around ulcer : While it can be important to rule out malignancy or to assess for other inflammatory processes, this area may not yield the specific viral inclusions or affected cells needed for a definitive viral diagnosis.
  • • Option C. Adjacent indurated area around ulcer
  • • rule out malignancy
  • • inflammatory processes,
  • • specific viral inclusions or affected cells
  • • definitive viral diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Surrounding normal mucosa : Sampling the normal mucosa is typically not helpful in diagnosing viral esophagitis because the characteristic histologic changes are seen in the affected tissue , not in the normal mucosa .
  • • Option D.
  • • Surrounding normal mucosa
  • • not helpful in diagnosing viral esophagitis
  • • histologic changes
  • • affected tissue
  • • normal mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When suspecting viral esophagitis , it is imperative to biopsy the edge of the ulcer for HSV and the base of the ulcer for CMV to increase the likelihood of an accurate diagnosis. This targeted approach leverages the pathophysiological differences in how these viruses affect the esophageal tissue , thereby facilitating appropriate treatment .
  • ➤ viral esophagitis
  • ➤ biopsy the edge of the ulcer for HSV
  • ➤ base of the ulcer for CMV
  • ➤ accurate diagnosis.
  • ➤ leverages
  • ➤ pathophysiological differences
  • ➤ esophageal tissue
  • ➤ facilitating appropriate treatment

questions.text: Nerve biopsy in leprosy is usually taken from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sural nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve is not commonly biopsied in cases of leprosy. While it is a major nerve in the forearm and hand, it is not typically involved in leprosy-related neuropathies.
  • • Option A. Ulnar nerve.
  • • Option B. Median nerve. The median nerve is also not commonly biopsied in leprosy cases. Leprosy typically affects peripheral nerves more distally in the limbs, and the median nerve may not be as frequently involved.
  • • Option B. Median nerve.
  • • Option C. Lateral popliteal nerve. The lateral popliteal nerve is commonly affected by leprosy neuropathy. It supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg and provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot and the web space between the first and second toes. Biopsy of this nerve is often undertaken in cases of suspected leprosy neuropathy to confirm the diagnosis.
  • • Option C. Lateral popliteal nerve.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The sural nerve, located in the lower leg, is a common site for nerve biopsy in cases of leprosy. It is a sensory nerve that provides innervation to the lateral aspect of the foot and ankle. Biopsy of the sural nerve can provide valuable diagnostic information in cases of suspected leprosy neuropathy.
  • • The sural nerve, located in the lower leg, is a common site for nerve biopsy in cases of leprosy.
  • • It is a sensory nerve that provides innervation to the lateral aspect of the foot and ankle.
  • • Biopsy of the sural nerve can provide valuable diagnostic information in cases of suspected leprosy neuropathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent anaphylaxis. As part of the diagnostic workup, a biopsy from a suspected lesion was taken and stained with Toluidine blue. Which type of cell is most likely to be highlighted by this stain in the patient's tissue sample?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mast cell

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Macrophages are phagocytic immune cells involved in the inflammatory response and tissue repair . They do not have a high affinity for Toluidine blue staining.
  • • Option A.
  • • Macrophages
  • • phagocytic immune cells
  • • inflammatory response
  • • tissue repair
  • • high affinity for Toluidine blue staining.
  • • Option B. Plasma cells are antibody-producing cells derived from B lymphocytes . They have abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum for antibody production but are not specifically stained by Toluidine blue.
  • • Option B.
  • • Plasma cells
  • • antibody-producing cells derived from B lymphocytes
  • • abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum for antibody production
  • • Option D. Eosinophils are involved in combating parasitic infections and allergic reactions . They contain eosinophilic granules but are not specifically highlighted by Toluidine blue.
  • • Option D.
  • • Eosinophils
  • • parasitic infections and allergic reactions
  • • eosinophilic granules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toluidine blue is a metachromatic dye with an affinity for acidic tissue components , particularly the granules in mast cells , which makes it a valuable stain for identifying these cells in tissue sections.
  • ➤ Toluidine blue
  • ➤ metachromatic dye
  • ➤ acidic tissue components
  • ➤ granules in mast cells
  • ➤ for identifying these cells in tissue sections.
  • ➤ (Ref: Robbins 10th/e p206)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was investigated for infertility. Semen analysis revealed azoospermia and biopsy was taken which is shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis in the patient?
questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Orchitis usually presents with signs of inflammation, not solely with the absence of germ cells as in the biopsy image.
  • • Option A.
  • • Orchitis
  • • Option C . Testicular atrophy involves shrinkage and decreased cellular density in the seminiferous tubules, ofte accompanied by fibrosis, which is not demonstrated in the biopsy provided.
  • • Option C
  • • Testicular atrophy
  • • Option D . Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors typically display malignant cells with various histologic patterns, which are not evident in the biopsy image.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Sertoli cell only syndrome, also known as germ cell aplasia, is diagnosed when testicular biopsy reveals seminiferous tubules with only Sertoli cells and an absence of germ cells, correlating with clinical findings of azoospermia and infertility in a male patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is a form of programmed cell death that is dependent on the formation of autophagosomes and leads to the degradation of cellular components?
questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Necroptosis
  • • resembles necrosis
  • • cell swelling and membrane rupture,
  • • TNFR1
  • • Option B. Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death involving cell shrinkage, DNA fragmentation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, without the formation of autophagosomes .
  • • Option B. Apoptosis
  • • programmed cell death
  • • cell shrinkage, DNA fragmentation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, without the formation of autophagosomes
  • • Option C. Pyroptosis is an inflammatory form of programmed cell death that occurs upon activation of inflammasomes and leads to cell lysis and inflammation, not primarily involving autophagosomes.
  • • Option C. Pyroptosis
  • • inflammatory form of programmed cell death
  • • not primarily involving autophagosomes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autophagy is a form of programmed cell death characterized by the formation of autophagosomes that engulf and degrade cellular components in response to cellular stress.

  • ➤ engulf and degrade cellular components

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the isoelectric pH (pI) of a molecule is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The molecule carries no net charge

options.label: B
options.text: Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

options.label: C
options.text: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins are mainly due to Histidine residue.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no mobility in an electric field

questions.correct_answer: B. Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: The molecule carries no net charge - This is correct . At the isoelectric point, the number of positive charges equals the number of negative charges , resulting in no net charge .
  • • Option A: The molecule carries no net charge -
  • • correct
  • • isoelectric
  • • positive charges equals
  • • negative charges
  • • no net charge
  • • Option C: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins is mainly due to Histidine residue - This statement is generally correct as histidine residues in proteins, such as those in plasma proteins , play a significant role in buffering due to the pKa of the histidine side chain being close to physiological pH.
  • • Option C: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins is mainly due to Histidine residue -
  • • correct
  • • histidine
  • • proteins,
  • • plasma proteins
  • • buffering
  • • pKa of the histidine side chain
  • • physiological pH.
  • • Option D: There is no mobility in an electric field - This is correct. Since the molecule has no net charge at its isoelectric point , it will not move towards either electrode in an electric field .
  • • Option D: There is no mobility in an electric field -
  • • correct.
  • • no net charge
  • • isoelectric point
  • • not
  • • either electrode
  • • electric field

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pH at which the molecule carries no net charge is called an isoelectric point or isoelectric pH (pI). At an isoelectric point , the amino acid will carry no net charge, all the groups are ionized but the charges will cancel each other. Hence, at isoelectric point, there is no mobility in an electrical field. Solubility and buffering capacity will be minimum at isoelectric pH. The buffering capacity of plasma proteins and hemoglobin is mainly due to histidine residue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of jaundice was subjected to a direct Van den Bergh reaction as part of his diagnostic workup. The test came positive. Based on these results, which type of bilirubin is present in the patient's blood serum that would cause a positive direct Van den Bergh’s reaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conjugated bilirubin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Van den Bergh reaction
  • • conjugated (direct) bilirubin
  • • unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin
  • • Conjugated bilirubin is water-soluble because it has been conjugated with glucuronic acid in the liver. It reacts directly with diazotized sulfanilic acid (diazo reagent) to form a purple azo dye — without requiring alcohol. This immediate reaction is called a Direct Positive Van den Bergh Test .
  • • Conjugated bilirubin is water-soluble because it has been conjugated with glucuronic acid in the liver. It reacts directly with diazotized sulfanilic acid (diazo reagent) to form a purple azo dye — without requiring alcohol. This immediate reaction is called a Direct Positive Van den Bergh Test .
  • • Conjugated bilirubin
  • • water-soluble
  • • directly
  • • diazotized sulfanilic acid (diazo reagent)
  • • purple azo dye
  • • Direct Positive Van den Bergh Test
  • • So, a positive direct reaction means conjugated bilirubin is present.
  • • positive direct reaction
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B — Unconjugated (free) bilirubin: Incorrect. Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and does not react directly in an aqueous solution with the diazo reagent. It needs to be dissolved in alcohol first, and then the test becomes positive. This is called an indirect reaction . Option C — Urobilinogen: Incorrect. Urobilinogen is tested with Ehrlich’s reagent (p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde) , not the diazo reagent, and forms a red color . Option D — Bile salts: Incorrect. Bile salts are detected by Hay’s sulfur test , which relies on surface tension reduction, not a colorimetric diazo reaction.
  • • Option B — Unconjugated (free) bilirubin: Incorrect. Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and does not react directly in an aqueous solution with the diazo reagent. It needs to be dissolved in alcohol first, and then the test becomes positive. This is called an indirect reaction .
  • • Option B — Unconjugated (free) bilirubin:
  • • water-insoluble
  • • not react directly
  • • alcohol
  • • indirect reaction
  • • Option C — Urobilinogen: Incorrect. Urobilinogen is tested with Ehrlich’s reagent (p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde) , not the diazo reagent, and forms a red color .
  • • Option C — Urobilinogen:
  • • Ehrlich’s reagent (p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde)
  • • red color
  • • Option D — Bile salts: Incorrect. Bile salts are detected by Hay’s sulfur test , which relies on surface tension reduction, not a colorimetric diazo reaction.
  • • Option D — Bile salts:
  • • Hay’s sulfur test

questions.text: Irregular thigh folds are seen in:

In addition, the legs may be of different length because of an adduction contracture or a collapsed epiphysis. The thigh folds appear normal.
  • • Option B. Perthes disease:
  • • Option C. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis: A child presenting with a chronic slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) will generally walk with an antalgic gait, out-toeing and some shortening of the affected limb. The child may complain of vague pain in the groin, thigh or knee.
  • • Option C. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis:
  • • Option D. Congenital coxa vara: The child presents with a painless limp resulting from Trendelenburg gait and minor limb length inequality. Easy fatigability or aching pain around the gluteal muscles may be a complaint.

  • • lymphocytic infiltrate
  • • Option D . Ductal carcinoma in situ represents an early form of breast cancer that is confined to the ducts and usually forms duct-like structures, unlike the pattern described.

  • • in situ

  • • confined to the ducts

questions.text: A middle-aged male working in an industrial setting presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, and poorly coordinated movements. He undergoes an eye examination, which reveals the findings depicted in the provided image. Based on these symptoms and eye findings, which gene is most likely mutated in this condition, and which mineral would be appropriate to administer as part of the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. ATP7B gene and zinc

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. ATP7A gene and zinc : Mutations in the ATP7A gene cause Menkes disease, not Wilson's disease, which is characterized by kinky hair, growth failure, and deterioration of the nervous system. Zinc is not the treatment for Menkes disease; instead, early copper-histidine injections are sometimes used.
  • • Option B. ATP7A gene and zinc
  • • Option C. ATP7A gene and magnesium : As mentioned, mutations in the ATP7A gene lead to Menkes disease. Magnesium is not related to the treatment of either Wilson's or Menkes disease, and there's no known link between the ATP7A gene and magnesium supplementation.
  • • Option C. ATP7A gene and magnesium
  • • Option D. ATP7B gene and selenium : While the ATP7B gene is associated with Wilson's disease, selenium supplementation is not a treatment for this condition. Selenium is more commonly associated with antioxidant properties and thyroid function.
  • • Option D. ATP7B gene and selenium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to copper accumulation primarily in the liver and brain. Clinical manifestations include hepatic dysfunction, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings in the cornea. Treatment involves copper chelation therapy with drugs like D-penicillamine and zinc supplementation which reduces intestinal copper absorption. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent irreversible organ damage.
  • ➤ Ref : Vasudevan 9/ed: p 521.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A 24-year-old researcher is studying the antioxidant defense mechanisms in the human body and is particularly interested in the role of glutathione. While reviewing the literature, he encounters various functions and characteristics of glutathione but finds conflicting information regarding one of its roles. Based on your knowledge, which of the following statements about glutathione (GSH) is NOT true?

options.label: D
options.text: It is a cofactor of various enzymes

questions.correct_answer: B. It converts hemoglobin to methaemoglobin
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

  • • Option A. True, as glutathione is composed of three amino acids: glutamate, cysteine, and glycine.
  • • Option
  • • A. True, as glutathione is composed of three amino acids:
  • • Option C. True , glutathione plays a significant role in the detoxification process by conjugating with various xenobiotics, aiding in their excretion from the body.
  • • Option C. True
  • • Option D. True , glutathione acts as a cofactor for glutathione peroxidase and other enzymes involved in the reduction of peroxides and maintenance of redox status within cells.
  • • Option D. True

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G lutathione does not convert haemoglobin to methaemoglobin . Methaemoglobin formation occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state , which can happen through various mechanisms , but not directly due to glutathione. In fact, glutathione plays a role in reducing oxidative stress in cells and can help to protect against the oxidation of hemoglobin.

questions.text: During a biochemistry seminar, the discussion turns to the regulation of metabolic pathways by allosteric enzymes. These enzymes are unique because their activity can be modulated by molecules binding to sites other than the active site. Which of the following statements correctly describes a feature of allosteric enzymes?

options.label: B
options.text: All the allosteric enzymes possess positive cooperativity

options.label: C
options.text: Allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue

options.label: D
options.text: Activity of allosteric enzymes is described by Michaelis-Menten equation

questions.correct_answer: C. Allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • substrate binds
  • • another separate allosteric site
  • • modifier binds

  • • combination of both positive
  • • negative cooperativity is observed
  • • sigmoid shaped curve
  • • Option D. Not by Michaelis-Menten equation . Allosteric enzymes often display sigmoidal kinetics due to their regulatory mechanisms , which are not captured by the Michaelis-Menten model that assumes a hyperbolic relationship between enzyme activity and substrate concentration.
  • • Option D.

  • ➤ Salient features of allosteric inhibition:
  • ➤ The inhibitor is not a substrate analog. It is partially reversible , when excess substrate is added . Km is usually increased and Vmax is reduced . The effect of an allosteric modifier is maximum at or near substrate concentration equivalent to Km. When an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site, the configuration of the catalytic site is modified such that the substrate cannot bind properly. Most allosteric enzymes possess quaternary structure and are made up of subunits , e.g. Aspartate transcarbamoylase: 6 subunits and pyruvate kinase: 4 subunits.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man patient presents with palpable purpura with bilateral knee joint involvement. Upon urinalysis is RBC and protein is noted. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) is characterized by a low platelet count , leading to easy bruising and bleeding . However, it does not typically involve the joints , and significant renal manifestations such as hematuria and proteinuria are not associated with ITP.

  • • low platelet count

  • • does not

  • • not associated with ITP.
  • • Option B. Chikungunya is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes . It can cause joint pain , but it does not typically present with palpable purpura or significant renal involvement.
  • • Option B. Chikungunya
  • • mosquitoes
  • • joint pain
  • • does not
  • • palpable purpura
  • • renal involvement.
  • • Option D. Dengue fever can cause thrombocytopenia, leading to bleeding manifestations . However, it is not commonly associated with palpable purpura or the specific joint and renal involvement described in the scenario.
  • • Option D. Dengue
  • • fever
  • • thrombocytopenia,
  • • bleeding manifestations
  • • not
  • • palpable purpura or the specific joint and renal involvement
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • HSP is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: palpable purpura, arthritis or arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement . The presence of palpable purpura , which are raised lesions resulting from the leakage of blood into the skin , is a hallmark of the disease. Arthralgia typically affects the knees and ankles and is usually symmetric. Renal involvement manifests as hematuria and proteinuria and can lead to more serious kidney damage if left untreated.

questions.text: In the outpatient department, three patients suspected of having dysglycemia underwent an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Their plasma glucose levels were measured at intervals after glucose ingestion, as depicted in the graph. Based on their glucose level trends, which patient most likely represents a pre-diabetic state?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Patient 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pre-diabetes (also called impaired glucose tolerance) is characterized by blood glucose levels that are higher than normal but not high enough to be classified as diabetes. In an OGTT, pre-diabetes typically shows:
  • • Fasting glucose that may be slightly elevated (100-125 mg/dL) A 2-hour post-load glucose between 140-199 mg/dL
  • • Fasting glucose that may be slightly elevated (100-125 mg/dL)
  • • A 2-hour post-load glucose between 140-199 mg/dL
  • • Analyzing each patient:
  • • Patient 1 (red squares):
  • • Starting glucose ~90 mg/dL (normal fasting) Returns to ~100 mg/dL by 120 min This represents a normal glucose tolerance pattern
  • • Starting glucose ~90 mg/dL (normal fasting)
  • • Returns to ~100 mg/dL by 120 min
  • • This represents a normal glucose tolerance pattern
  • • Patient 2 (blue triangles):
  • • Starting glucose ~80 mg/dL Slow decline but remains elevated at ~145 mg/dL at 120 min This pattern shows impaired glucose tolerance (pre-diabetes) with delayed return to normal
  • • Starting glucose ~80 mg/dL
  • • Slow decline but remains elevated at ~145 mg/dL at 120 min
  • • This pattern shows impaired glucose tolerance (pre-diabetes) with delayed return to normal
  • • Patient 3 (green circles):
  • • Starting glucose ~140 mg/dL (already elevated at fasting) Remains very elevated at 120 min (~210 mg/dL) This pattern is consistent with diabetes mellitus
  • • Starting glucose ~140 mg/dL (already elevated at fasting)
  • • Remains very elevated at 120 min (~210 mg/dL)
  • • This pattern is consistent with diabetes mellitus
  • • Patient 2 best represents pre-diabetes because their fasting level is normal but they show impaired glucose tolerance with the 2-hour value remaining elevated at ~145 mg/d.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The OGTT is used to assess how well the body clears glucose from the bloodstream. In a pre-diabetic state , the 2-hour glucose value is elevated beyond normal but does not reach diabetic levels (140–199 mg/dL). If the value is ≥200 mg/dL, a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus is made.
  • ➤ pre-diabetic state
  • ➤ 2-hour glucose value
  • ➤ diabetes mellitus
  • ➤ Ref: Harper 30/e p 337 -340.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of heavy smoking complains of chronic cough. On chest radiograph, he has a suspicious lesion on the right upper lobe. Bronchoscopy and biopsy reveals that the mass has bronchial mucosa displays squamous metaplasia. What is the most likely outcome of this lesion if the said individual stops smoking?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reversion to normal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atrophy refers to the shrinkage in the size of the cell by loss of cell substance . When it comes to bronchial epithelium, atrophy is less common as a direct result of cessation of smoking.
  • • Option A. Atrophy
  • • shrinkage in the size of the cell
  • • loss of cell substance
  • • bronchial epithelium, atrophy is less common
  • • Option B. Malignant transformation is the process by which cells acquire the abilities to form a malignancy or cancer. Squamous metaplasia can be a precursor to squamous cell carcinoma ; however, it is a potentially reversible process, and the risk of malignant transformation decreases if the irritating stimulus , in this case, smoking, is removed .
  • • Option B. Malignant transformation
  • • cells acquire the abilities to form a malignancy or cancer.
  • • precursor to squamous cell carcinoma
  • • reversible process,
  • • risk of malignant transformation decreases
  • • irritating stimulus
  • • smoking, is removed
  • • Option C. Necrosis and scarring would occur as a result of cell death and tissue damage. This is more typical of an end-stage process of persistent damage , rather than a result of the cessation of smoking.
  • • Option C. Necrosis and scarring
  • • result of cell death and tissue damage.
  • • end-stage process of persistent damage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Squamous metaplasia in the bronchial epithelium due to chronic irritation from smoking is a reversible process, and upon cessation of smoking , the epithelium has the potential to revert to its normal state.
  • ➤ Squamous metaplasia
  • ➤ bronchial epithelium
  • ➤ smoking is a reversible process,
  • ➤ cessation of smoking
  • ➤ revert to its normal state.
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th / 61

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with progressive dyspnea and a chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests impaired expiratory flow. Chest imaging shows reveal hyperinflation. Which type of emphysema is most commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Centriacinar

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Panacinar Emphysema: Panacinar emphysema involves the destruction of the entire respiratory acinus, including the respiratory bronchiole, alveolar ducts, and alveoli. It is often associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
  • • Option A. Panacinar Emphysema:
  • • destruction of the entire respiratory acinus,
  • • respiratory bronchiole, alveolar ducts, and alveoli.
  • • alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
  • • Option C. Paraseptal Emphysema: Paraseptal emphysema, also known as distal acinar emphysema, involves the distal parts of the acinus , particularly the alveolar ducts and alveoli near the pleura . It often occurs adjacent to scars or fibrotic tissue , and it is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax.
  • • Option C. Paraseptal Emphysema:
  • • distal acinar emphysema,
  • • distal parts of the acinus
  • • alveolar ducts and alveoli near the pleura
  • • occurs adjacent to scars or fibrotic tissue
  • • spontaneous pneumothorax.
  • • Option D. Segmental Emphysema: Segmental emphysema refers to localized areas of emphysematous changes within a lung segment . It can occur in association with scarring or inflammation . While it is less common than other types of emphysema, it may contribute to localized airflow obstruction.
  • • Option D. Segmental Emphysema:
  • • localized areas of emphysematous changes
  • • lung segment
  • • scarring or inflammation
  • • less common
  • • types of emphysema,
  • • localized airflow obstruction.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Centriacinar emphysema , is most commonly associated with cigarette smoking and predominantly affects the central parts of the acinus , leading to symptoms like progressive dyspnea and chronic cough in smokers .
  • ➤ Centriacinar emphysema
  • ➤ cigarette smoking and predominantly
  • ➤ central parts of the acinus
  • ➤ progressive dyspnea and chronic cough in smokers

questions.text: In the context of glucose metabolism and insulin action, GLUT4 is characterized as a glucose transporter. Is it accurate to state that GLUT4's activity is regulated by insulin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) True.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • GLUT4 is the major glucose transporter seen in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue . GLUT4 is under the control of insulin . Insulin promotes the translocation of intracellular GLUT4 molecules to the cell surface and thus increases glucose uptake. In Type 2 diabetes mellitus , membrane GLUT4 is reduced causing insulin resistance in muscle and fat cells. In diabetes, entry of glucose into muscle is only half of normal cells.

questions.text: The posterolateral lesion in the head of humerus in cases of recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hill-Sachs lesion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bankart’s lesion . In the Bankart’s lesion, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of t the neck of the scapula. The Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.
  • • Option A. Bankart’s lesion
  • • Option C. Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion . Reverse Hill-Sachs defect, also known as a McLaughlin lesion, is defined as an impaction fracture of anteromedial aspect of the humeral head following posterior dislocation of the humerus.
  • • Option C. Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion
  • • Option D. Greater tuberosity avulsion fracture . The greater tuberosity is the attachment site of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor tendons. Isolated fractures of the greater tuberosity are uncommon. Occasionally, a Hill–Sachs lesion in the humeral head may be confused with a fracture of the greater tuberosity.
  • • Option D. Greater tuberosity avulsion fracture
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The posterolateral lesion in the humeral head due to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is called as the Hill-Sachs lesion.
  • • The posterolateral lesion in the humeral head due to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is called as the Hill-Sachs lesion.

questions.text: Tinel’s sign is:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with fatigue and widespread purpura. Blood work reveals a marked decrease in platelets, with counts persistently below 20,000/µL. The patient's history includes recurrent epistaxis and one instance of hematuria. Bone marrow biopsy reveals a hypocellular marrow with a markedly reduced number of megakaryocytes. All of the following can cause megakaryocytic thrombocytopenia, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aplastic anemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura [ITP]: ITP is characterized by autoimmune destruction of platelets . It typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and may show an increased number of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow due to compensatory production.
  • • Option A. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura [ITP]:
  • • autoimmune destruction of platelets
  • • Option B. Systemic lupus erythematosus [SLE]: SLE can cause thrombocytopenia due to autoantibody-mediated platelet destruction . Megakaryocytes may be increased in the bone marrow as the body tries to compensate for the peripheral platelet destruction.
  • • Option B. Systemic lupus erythematosus [SLE]:
  • • cause thrombocytopenia
  • • autoantibody-mediated platelet destruction
  • • Option D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation [DIC]: DIC is a condition that leads to the systemic activation of the coagulation cascade , resulting in widespread microthrombi and secondary consumption of platelets and coagulation factors . This can also lead to a compensatory increase in megakaryocytes in the bone marrow.
  • • Option D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation [DIC]:
  • • leads to the systemic activation of the coagulation cascade
  • • widespread microthrombi
  • • secondary consumption of platelets
  • • coagulation factors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In megakaryocytic thrombocytopenia , there is an increase in bone marrow megakaryocytes as a compensatory mechanism for peripheral platelet destruction , but in aplastic anemia, there is bone marrow failure and reduced megakaryocytes.
  • ➤ megakaryocytic thrombocytopenia
  • ➤ increase in bone marrow megakaryocytes
  • ➤ compensatory mechanism
  • ➤ peripheral platelet destruction

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive involuntary movements in her right hand and visual difficulties noted over the past year. Blood work reveals elevated serum homocysteine with normal liver, renal, thyroid function tests, and electrolytes. She responds favorably to high-dose pyridoxine and a methionine-restricted diet, with a noted improvement in dystonic movements after three months. What condition is most likely affecting this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hartnup’s disease: Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine.
  • • Option A. Hartnup’s disease:
  • • defective absorption of aromatic amino acids
  • • intestine
  • • reabsorption from renal tubules
  • • Option B. Cystinuria: Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system →patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream →accumulation of cystine in urine forms stones →leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis, obstruction, and finally renal failure.
  • • Option B. Cystinuria:
  • • defect/deficiency of transporter system
  • • bloodstream
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionase deficiency , patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies.
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria:
  • • cystathionase deficiency
  • • mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • • endocrinopathies.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classical homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, leading to elevated homocysteine levels . Treatment with high-dose pyridoxine (vitamin B6), a cofactor for the enzyme , can improve symptoms , and a methionine-restricted diet can help manage homocysteine levels . The improvement in dystonia with treatment supports this diagnosis.
  • ➤ Classical homocystinuria
  • ➤ deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase,
  • ➤ elevated homocysteine levels
  • ➤ high-dose pyridoxine
  • ➤ cofactor for the enzyme
  • ➤ improve symptoms
  • ➤ methionine-restricted diet

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness and a sharp pain in his chest. He had been lifting heavy objects and moving around a lot that day. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

In more significant effusions, there might be a meniscus sign, but there would not be lung collapse as seen with pneumothorax.

  • • Option D. Aortic Dissection
  • • not directly affect lung volumes
  • • cause tracheal deviation
